List of Reported UFO Sightings ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia article provides a compilation of notable reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), including claims of close encounters and alien abduction. It clarifies that UFOs encompass any aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified, noting that most are eventually explained as known objects or atmospheric phenomena. The article also mentions the use of the term “Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena” (UAP) to avoid associations with UFO conspiracy theories.

Antiquity ðŸ”—

This section details alleged UFO sightings from ancient times, drawing from historical texts.

  • c. 1450 BC: The Tulli Papyrus describes an event during Thutmose III’s reign in Ancient Egypt, where a “star came down” and set fire to his adversaries.
  • 218 BC: Reports from the Roman Republic in Italia mention “phantom navy” seen shining in the sky.
  • 76 BC: An account from Asia (Roman Republic) describes a “spark” falling from a star, growing to the size of the Moon, and then transforming into a torch.
  • 73 BC: Plutarch recounts a “flame-like body” resembling a wine-jar (pithos) falling between Roman and Pontic armies in Phrygia.
  • AD 65: Flavius Josephus reports chariots “hurtling through the clouds” in Judaea before the First Jewishâ€“Roman War.
  • AD 196: Cassius Dio describes a “fine rain resembling silver” falling from a clear sky in Rome.

8th Century ðŸ”—

This section contains a single entry:

  • c. AD 740: The “Air ship of Clonmacnoise” is recorded in Irish annals, describing “ships with their crews were seen in the air” over Teltown and Clonmacnoise in Ireland.

16thâ€“17th Centuries ðŸ”—

This section lists reports from the Renaissance and early modern periods.

  • 1561: A celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg, Bavaria, is described as an aerial battle with spheres, cylinders, and other odd-shaped objects.
  • 1566: A broadsheet depicts spherical objects appearing out of the sun over Basel, Switzerland.
  • 1609: Multiple witnesses in Joseon (Korea) describe a Halo or washbowl that was divided in two in the sky.

19th Century ðŸ”—

This section covers sightings from the 1800s.

  • 1883: Astronomer JosÃ© Bonilla photographed hundreds of dark objects crossing the sun at the Zacatecas Observatory in Mexico.
  • 1896-1897: Reports of “mystery airships” with bright lights and cigar-shaped bodies appear in newspapers across California and the Midwest United States.
  • 1897: S.E. Hayden reports the crash of an airship piloted by an alien in Aurora, Texas.

20th Century ðŸ”—

This section is divided into two sub-sections: 1900-1949 and 1950-1974.

1900â€“1949 ðŸ”—

This section covers the early to mid-20th century.

  • 1904: Crew members aboard the USS Supply report seeing three “bright red” objects in geometrical formation flight pattern in the North Pacific.
  • 1907: Fighters of Ã‡erÃ§iz Topulli in Albania report seeing a shiny object suspended in the air.
  • 1909: Moving lights are reported in the sky around Otago, New Zealand, followed by more sightings across the country.
  • 1917: Thousands gather in FÃ¡tima, Portugal, and claim to see bizarre solar activity, later interpreted as a mass UFO sighting.
  • 1926: Nicholas Roerich reports an oval object in the sky above his caravan in Tibet.
  • 1933: Frank Smythe witnesses two spots hovering and pulsating in the sky near Mount Everest.
  • 1940s: Allied fighter pilots report colorful balls of light following their aircraft during World War II (Foo fighters).
  • 1941: A local legend emerges in Cape Girardeau, Missouri, about a crashed flying saucer and its dying crew.
  • 1942: Anti-aircraft artillery fires thousands of rounds at an unidentified aerial object over Los Angeles, California (Battle of Los Angeles).
  • 1942: Control tower operator near Flying School, Columbus, Missouri observes two reddish colored round objects descend-hover-accelerate away.
  • 1944: 468th Bomb Group reports an intense red or orange object that throbbed or vibrated constantly.
  • 1945: Conflicting accounts emerge regarding an avocado-shaped craft piloted by insectoid aliens crashing at the Trinity nuclear test site in New Mexico.
  • 1946: Thousands of UFO sightings are reported over Europe (Ghost Rockets), prompting investigations by the Swedish and Greek governments.
  • 1946: Swedish entrepreneur GÃ¶sta Carlsson commemorates a 1946 UFO encounter with a concrete monument in Ã„ngelholm, Sweden.
  • 1947: Private pilot Kenneth Arnold reports seeing a group of reflective craft moving at high speeds near Mount Rainier, Washington, coining the term “flying saucers.”
  • 1947: Over 800 similar sightings are reported throughout 1947 after the Kenneth Arnold sighting.
  • 1947: A United Airlines crew witnesses nine unidentified objects en route from Boise, Idaho, to Pendleton, Oregon.
  • 1947: William Albert Rhodes takes photographs of a silent grey object in Phoenix, Arizona.
  • 1947: Walter Haut issues a press release announcing the “capture” of a “flying saucer” near Roswell, New Mexico, later retracted as a weather balloon.
  • 1947: Fred Crisman mails an account of flying doughnut-shaped objects and threats from Men in Black to Raymond A. Palmer (Maury Island hoax).
  • 1948: Reports of green flares streaking across the sky are investigated by the US Air Force (The Green Fireballs).

  • 1948: A US Air Force pilot sights and pursues a UFO for 27 minutes over Fargo, North Dakota (Gorman dogfight).

1950â€“1974 ðŸ”—

This section covers the mid to late 20th century.

  • 1950: A farmer takes pictures of a purported “flying saucer” near McMinnville, Oregon.
  • 1950: The manager of Great Falls’ pro baseball team took color film of two UFOs flying over Great Falls, Montana.
  • 1951: Two pilots and a military officer passenger aboard a commercial DC-3 reported being buzzed by an unidentified straight-winged plane over Sioux City, Iowa.

  • 1955: Eleven people witnessed creatures in the night at a rural farmhouse near Hopkinsville, Kentucky.

List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Africa ðŸ”—

This is a compilation of reported Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) sightings across various countries in Africa.

Algeria ðŸ”—

This section details alleged UFO sightings during the Algerian War (1954â€“1962) around conflict zones. A specific incident from March 1958 is highlighted, where a soldier reported witnessing a large, elliptical craft with green lights and a beam of light. In March 1975, multiple UFOs were reportedly observed by several people across the country.

Benin ðŸ”—

This section simply states that reports were received from Benin, but does not provide any specific details.

Botswana ðŸ”—

This section lists two specific UFO sightings in Botswana: one in the Okavango Delta on June 25, 2016, and another in Gaberone on May 14, 2008.

Morocco ðŸ”—

This section describes three UFO sightings in July 1952. The first involved two elongated flying saucers spotted by policemen above Had Kourt. The second involved inhabitants of Fedala spotting a blue-green, ball-shaped object. The third involved a couple observing another flying saucer.

Senegal ðŸ”—

This section details a UFO sighting above Dakar on July 3, 1952. The object was described as a flat, tapered saucer surrounded by flames, moving at high speed.

South Africa ðŸ”—

This section refers to a main article dedicated to UFO sightings in South Africa.

Sudan ðŸ”—

This section describes a UFO sighting in January 2018 over Khartoum. The Sudanese military identified it as a potential satellite, possibly the failed US satellite Zuma, but admitted they could not clearly identify the object.

Tunisia ðŸ”—

This section recounts a UFO sighting in July 1969, where many observers, including US embassy officials, reported a large, two-part green-blue object in the sky of Tunis. The object reportedly exploded, forming a greenish circular cloud.

The children described the aliens as having large heads, slits for mouths, and dark suits. American psychiatrist John E. Mack interviewed the children and concluded that the incident was likely not mass hysteria, as the children gave consistent accounts.

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction ðŸ”—

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. These individuals are often referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” While most scientists and mental health professionals attribute these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology, some researchers give credence to the claims. Typical claims involve forced medical examinations, often focusing on reproductive systems, warnings about environmental abuses and nuclear weapons, or interspecies breeding. The content of these narratives often varies with the abductee’s cultural background.

Overview ðŸ”—

Mainstream scientists generally reject the literal interpretation of alien abduction claims. However, some, like psychiatrist John E. Mack, argue that many abductees are sane individuals, with psychopathology only present in some cases. Detailed abduction reports have led to the development of a subculture with support groups and a complex mythos explaining the roles, origins, and motivations of various alien types, such as Greys, Reptilians, and Nordics. Some abductees engage in independent research and attribute the lack of wider awareness to extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History ðŸ”—

Paleo-abductions ðŸ”—

Before the widespread attention to alien abduction in the 1960s, some older stories have been reinterpreted as possible early cases, termed “paleo-abductions” by UFO researcher Jerome Clark. One example is Colonel H. G. Shaw’s 1896 claim of being harassed by tall, slender humanoids. An article from 1953 asked if flying saucers were kidnapping humans for zoological specimens or vivisection. The 1955 publication of Harold T. Wilkins’s Flying Saucers Uncensored reported speculation that Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who claimed alien contact, disappeared due to abduction.

Two landmark cases ðŸ”—

The AntÃ´nio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil during the mid-1950s was an early claim but received limited attention initially. The Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961 gained widespread publicity, including a 1975 television film. The Hill incident is considered a prototypical abduction case, possibly the first to describe beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identify an extraterrestrial origin.

Later developments ðŸ”—

R. Leo Sprinkle, a psychologist at the University of Wyoming, became interested in the phenomenon in the 1960s and linked abductions to cattle mutilation. Budd Hopkins became a key figure in the abductee subculture in the 1970s, using hypnosis to uncover details of remembered events. The 1980s saw increased mainstream attention, with works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack presenting alien abduction as a plausible experience. Thomas E. Bullard’s comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees was also published.

Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was more common than previously thought, estimating tens of thousands of North Americans had been abducted. They also proposed an alien effort to create human-alien hybrids. While anecdotal reports of phantom pregnancies related to UFO encounters existed earlier, Hopkins and Jacobs popularized the idea of widespread interbreeding efforts.

According to Boston Globe writer Linda Rodriguez McRobbie, alien abduction stories have declined in mainstream media. Michael Shermer suggests that the ubiquity of camera phones has increased the burden of evidence, contributing to the decline.

John E. Mack ðŸ”—

Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce, writing in The Lancet, suggested that Mack’s work in hypnotic regression helped spread the Grey aliens meme. Mack interviewed over 800 people and wrote two books on the subject. His professional reputation suffered due to his belief and promotion of abduction claims, leading to a Harvard review in 1994.

Abductees ðŸ”—

The precise number of alleged abductees is uncertain. Early studies found 1,700 claimants, while contested surveys suggested 5â€“6 percent of the general population claim to have been abducted.

Demographics ðŸ”—

While abduction reports are usually made by adults, children sometimes report similar experiences. These reports often share specific details with adult reports, including circumstances, narrative, entities, and aftermaths. Young abductees often have family members who have reported abduction experiences, and family involvement in the military or residence near a military base is also common.

Mental health ðŸ”—

Some studies suggest that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that abductees are not different from the general population in terms of psychopathology prevalence. Elizabeth Slater’s blind study found abductees prone to “mildly paranoid thinking,” nightmares, and weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally’s study concluded that none of the abductees suffered from psychiatric illness.

Political conspiracy theories ðŸ”—

Political scientist Michael Barkun highlights links between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, environmental pollution, hidden groups, and government takeover. He observed the rise of “improvisional millenarism.” UFO and abduction stories can be part of stigmatized knowledge narratives. UFO and alien-related conspiracy theories emerged in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards.

According to Barkun, TV shows like The X-Files included aliens as part of coverup conspiracies, with militias and black helicopters, and demonized FEMA. Political scientist Jodi Dean noted that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities.

Self-described abduction victims often join self-help communities and may resort to questionable regression therapy. Some espouse conspiracy theories of technological mind control, including implants, to force them to serve a New World Order or for the purposes of the antichrist.

Abduction narrative ðŸ”—

Various researchers have noted common points in report narratives. CUFOS defines an abductee as someone taken against their will by non-human beings to an extraterrestrial place or spaceship, subjected to examination or communication, with memories that may be conscious or recovered through hypnosis.

Although cases vary, some UFO researchers argue that there is a fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.”

Bullard argues most abduction accounts feature the following events:

  1. Capture: The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures, and on occasion simulated behavioral situations, training & testing, or sexual liaisons.
  3. Conference: The abductors communicate with the abductee or direct them to interact with specific individuals for some purpose.
  4. Tour: The abductees are given a tour of their captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time: Abductees often rapidly forget the majority of their experience.
  6. Return: The abductees are returned to earth, occasionally in a different location or with new injuries.
  7. Theophany: Abductees may have a profound sense of love, a “high” similar to those induced by certain drugs, or a “mystical experience”.
  8. Aftermath: The abductee must cope with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs says that the entire abduction event is precisely orchestrated, with predetermined procedures.

Capture ðŸ”—

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the onset of an abduction experience, such as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place or expectations that something “familiar yet unknown” will occur. They also report feeling severe anxiety. Eventually, the experiencer will undergo an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness. External sounds cease to have any significance, and they report feeling introspective and unusually calm. As consciousness shifts, lights are alleged to appear, occasionally accompanied by a strange mist. As the alleged abduction proceeds, claimants say they will walk or be levitated into an alien craft, often through solid objects.

Examination ðŸ”—

The examination phase is characterized by medical procedures and examinations by alien beings against the will of the experiencer. Such procedures often focus on sex and reproductive biology. The entity in charge of the operation is often taller than the others and may appear to be of a different species.

Miller notes different areas of emphasis between human medicine and what is reported as being practiced by the abductors. The abductors’ areas of interest appear to be the cranium, nervous system, skin, reproductive system, and joints. Systems given less attention include the cardiovascular system, the respiratory system below the pharynx, and the lymphatic system. The abductors also appear to ignore the upper region of the abdomen in favor of the lower one. The abductors do not appear to wear gloves during the “examination.” Other constants of terrestrial medicine like pills and tablets are missing from abduction narratives, although sometimes abductees are asked to drink liquids.

Subsequent procedures ðŸ”—

After the medical exam, the alleged abductees often report other procedures being performed with the entities. Common among these post-examination procedures are imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing.

“Imaging” procedures consist of an abductee being made to view screens displaying images and scenes that appear to be specially chosen with the intent to provoke certain emotional responses in the abductee. “Envisioning” is a similar procedure, with the primary difference being that the images being viewed, rather than being on a screen, actually seem to be

This article lists alleged UFO sightings in Australia, spanning from the pre-1900s to recent times.

Pre 1900 ðŸ”—

This section details an 1868 sighting in Parramatta, New South Wales, where Alderman Frederick Birmingham reported seeing an ark-like object floating in the sky before landing in Parramatta Park.

1950s ðŸ”—

This section mentions a 1954 sighting in Gawler, South Australia, where three people observed a white UFO flying overhead, followed by an RAAF jet.

  • The 1966 Westall High School UFO incident in Clayton South, Victoria, where many students and staff claimed to have witnessed a UFO flying over the school and descending into a paddock.

1970s ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Valentich Disappearance in 1978. Frederick Valentich, a pilot, disappeared while flying a Cessna 182 over Bass Strait to King Island (Tasmania). He reported to Melbourne air traffic control that he was being accompanied by an unknown aircraft.

1980s ðŸ”—

This section describes a 1988 sighting in South Australia’s Nullarbor Plain. A family reported seeing a “big glowing ball” that resembled “an egg in an egg cup.”

1990s ðŸ”—

This section details two incidents:

  • In 1993, Eric Thomason photographed a craft hovering around Maslin Beach.
  • Also in 1993, Kelly Cahill from Melbourne claimed to have seen a large craft over the road in the Dandenong Ranges near Belgrave, Victoria, and further claimed to have been abducted by aliens.

2012 ðŸ”—

This section describes an alleged encounter in Frankston South, Victoria. A resident, K.T., reported being hit by a blinding light and later encountering a tall, white humanoid being identifying as a “Paladeian” from the “Star Cluster Pladieas.” K.T. claimed to have communicated telepathically with the being, experiencing paralysis and lost time during the encounter.

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens ðŸ”—

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and large, black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the image of Grey aliens.

Description ðŸ”—

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoids with grey skin, elongated bodies, small chests, and a lack of muscular definition. They are said to lack external human body parts like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their most striking feature is their disproportionately large heads with no hair and large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance ðŸ”—

This subsection further elaborates on the physical appearance of Grey aliens. They are generally depicted as lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. The most prominent feature is their large, black, almond-shaped eyes, often described as lacking eye whites. They are also frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli ðŸ”—

This subsection explains the origin of the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association began with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and determined that the aliens’ home was Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History ðŸ”—

Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition, and having disproportionately short legs. A key feature is their large heads relative to their bodies, devoid of hair, with small orifices for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their eyes are large, opaque, black, and almond-shaped. item.title: Interdimensional UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Interdimensional UFO Hypothesis ðŸ”—

The interdimensional UFO hypothesis (IUH) proposes that unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings result from encounters with other “dimensions” that coexist alongside our own. This idea is supported by ufologists who suggest that UFOs are a modern manifestation of phenomena throughout human history, previously attributed to mythological or supernatural beings.

History ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical context of the interdimensional UFO hypothesis, tracing its roots from pre-modern concepts to modern ufology.

Pre-modern history ðŸ”—

Concepts similar to “other dimensions” exist in various religious and mystical traditions. Islamic mysticism, known as Sufism, includes the concept of al-ghayb, referring to the hidden and unseen. Within this tradition, ‘Älam al-mithÄl, or “the world of similitude,” is considered an intermediary realm between the physical and spiritual worlds, inhabited by intelligent non-human entities such as jinn and angels.

Theorists ðŸ”—

This section introduces key figures who have advanced the interdimensional UFO hypothesis.

Background ðŸ”—

In the 19th century, spiritualists believed in “other dimensions.” H.P. Blavatsky popularized the term “planes,” proposing a cosmology of seven planes. The term “ether” was adopted from ancient Greek and incorporated into occult writings. Charles Webster Leadbeater and Annie Besant introduced the “etheric plane” and “etheric body” in Theosophy. The first use of the word, as inter-dimensional, is in a novel by Z Gale of 1906.

Meade Layne and ‘Ether Ships’ ðŸ”—

Meade Layne, an occultist, claimed in 1947 that flying discs were “etheric.” Layne claimed telepathic communication with “people in the saucers,” arguing that objects could pass from an etheric to a dense level of matter. He stated that these visitors were human beings living in their own world with good intentions. Layne is regarded as the earliest proponent of the interdimensional hypothesis.

John Keel and ‘Ultraterrestrials’ ðŸ”—

John Keel coined the term “ultraterrestrials” to describe UFO occupants as non-human entities existing in a wavelength of energy undetectable to us. In his book UFOs: Operation Trojan Horse, Keel argued that a non-human intelligence has staged events to propagate erroneous belief systems, including monsters, ghosts, demons, fairies, vampires, mystery airships, anomalous creatures, poltergeists, and UFOs.

Hynek and VallÃ©e ðŸ”—

J. Allen Hynek, an astronomer and scientific advisor to the U.S. Air Force UFO studies, pioneered the “Close Encounter” classification system. Jacques VallÃ©e, a student of Hynek, served as the inspiration for a character in the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind. In The Edge of Reality, VallÃ©e and Hynek considered the possibility of “interlocking universes.” VallÃ©e argued for a “parallel universe co-existing with our own” in his book Passport to Magonia. VallÃ©e’s 1990 paper “Five Arguments Against the Extraterrestrial Origin of Unidentified Flying Objects” summarized his objections to the extraterrestrial hypothesis.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section explores the presence of the interdimensional UFO hypothesis in popular culture.

The 2008 film Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull utilizes the interdimensional hypothesis, describing ancient aliens traveling into “the space between the spaces.” The 2014 movie Interstellar employs a mix of the interdimensional and time-traveler hypotheses, with future humans evolving to exist in five dimensions.

Other contrasting hypothesis ðŸ”—

This section contrasts the IUH with other hypotheses.

The IUH contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis, which suggests UFO sightings are caused by visitations from outside Earth, and the psychosocial hypothesis, which argues UFO sightings are best explained as psychological or social phenomena. Other contrasting hypotheses include the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, space animal hypothesis, and time-traveler hypothesis.

This section lists related topics.

item.title: David Grusch UFO whistleblower claims
item.description:
David Grusch: Former U.S. Military Intelligence Officer’s Claims About “Non-Human” Spacecraft Recovery ðŸ”—

This article focuses on the claims made by David Grusch, a former U.S. Air Force officer and intelligence official, regarding the U.S. government’s alleged involvement in recovering and reverse-engineering “non-human” spacecraft. It also covers the responses to these claims from various experts and government entities.

Background ðŸ”—

David Charles Grusch is introduced as an Afghanistan combat veteran and former intelligence officer who worked at the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) and the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO). From 2019 to 2021, he served as the NRO representative to the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force. He assisted in drafting the National Defense Authorization Act of 2023, which included whistleblower protections for UFO reporting. The section notes that Congressional interest in UFOs increased prior to Grusch’s claims due to the downing of four objects by the Air Force in February 2023.

Grusch’s Claims ðŸ”—

This section details Grusch’s allegations, which were initially reported by Leslie Kean and Ralph Blumenthal in The Debrief. Grusch claims the U.S. government possesses multiple spacecraft of “non-human” origin and the corpses of their pilots. He alleges a secret UFO retrieval program, “substantive evidence” of white-collar crime to conceal UFO programs, and that officials have stated people have been killed to conceal these programs.

In an interview with Le Parisien, Grusch elaborated, suggesting UFOs could be from extra dimensions, mentioning “football-field” sized crafts, the transfer of crashed UFOs to defense contractors, and “malevolent activity” by UFOs.

During a Congressional hearing in July 2023, Grusch testified about being informed of a multi-decade UAP crash retrieval and reverse-engineering program to which he was denied access. He stated his belief that the U.S. government possesses UAP based on interviews with 40 witnesses. He also claimed the U.S. has retrieved “non-human ‘biologics’” from the crafts. When asked about harm or injury related to cover-ups, Grusch said yes, but could only provide details in a SCIF.

Responses from Relevant Experts ðŸ”—

This section presents the views of various experts on Grusch’s claims. It highlights that his assertions are based on alleged documents and conversations, rather than testable evidence. The scientific community generally considers claims of government conspiracy to conceal extraterrestrial visitation untrue.

Joshua Semeter of NASA’s UAP independent study team states that without data or material evidence, evaluating the claims is impossible. Adam Frank, an astrophysics professor, criticizes the claims as hearsay and lacking extraordinary evidence.

Stuart Clark’s opinion piece in The Guardian includes questions from scientists like Avi Loeb, Michael Garrett, and Sara Russell, who point out the lack of observed extraterrestrial activity and the ease of identifying extraterrestrial materials.

Greg Eghigian, a history professor and UFO expert, notes the historical pattern of individuals making “bombshell allegations” about UFOs and the lack of corroboration. Seth Shostak, senior astronomer at the SETI Institute, questions the absence of physical evidence and dismisses the claims as an “argument from authority.” Michael Shermer, publisher of Skeptic magazine, notes the lack of physical evidence and scientific community involvement.

Physicist Sean M. Carroll calls Grusch’s claims “laughable” and describes him as a “complete crackpot.” NASA’s JPL director, Laurie Leshin, denies having seen spacecraft from outside this world. Michio Kaku suggests the burden of proof has shifted to the Pentagon, a statement criticized by Ross Pomeroy.

Responses from the United States Government ðŸ”—

This section outlines the responses from various U.S. government entities.

Department of Defense and NASA ðŸ”—

White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre referred questions to the Department of Defense (DoD). A Pentagon spokesperson stated that AARO has not discovered verifiable information to substantiate claims of programs regarding the possession or reverse-engineering of extraterrestrial materials. General Mark Milley stated he had never encountered evidence verifying Grusch’s claims. NASA stated it has not found credible evidence of extraterrestrial life and that there is no evidence that UAPs are extraterrestrial.

Congress ðŸ”—

Representative Mike Turner stated there is no evidence of the U.S. possessing UFOs from outer space. Senator Lindsey Graham found the claims unreasonable. Senator Josh Hawley said the allegations sounded close to what they were “grudgingly admitted to us in the briefing”. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand intends to hold a hearing to assess whether “rogue SAP programs” existed. Senator Marco Rubio said people with “first-hand knowledge” have shared information with his committee.

In July 2023, Senators Chuck Schumer and Mike Rounds proposed the UAP Disclosure Act 2023, an amendment to the 2024 National Defence Authorization Act, to provide wider access to UAP records. The enrolled bill directs the National Archives to collect government documents about UAP.

In January 2024, members of the House Oversight Committee received a classified briefing from the Intelligence Community Inspector General (IC IG) Thomas A. Monheim regarding UAP reporting transparency. Some members were frustrated by the lack of new information regarding Grusch’s allegations.

2023 House Committee Oversight and Accountability Hearing ðŸ”—

Representatives Anna Paulina Luna and Tim Burchett organized a hearing on July 26, 2023, in response to Grusch’s claims. Grusch testified, repeating his earlier UFO claims. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez asked where to look for evidence, and Grusch offered to provide specifics in a closed environment. Officials later informed lawmakers that Grusch lacked security clearance to discuss the issues in a SCIF. Following the hearing, a bipartisan group of U.S. representatives called for the formation of a select committee on UAPs with subpoena power.

AARO’s director Sean Kirkpatrick wrote that Grusch “has refused to speak with AARO” and that the hearing was “insulting”.

Sean Kirkpatrick ðŸ”—

After retiring from AARO, Kirkpatrick wrote an opinion piece for Scientific American stating that the US Government UFO coverup allegations “derive from inadvertent or unauthorized disclosures of legitimate U.S. programs or related R&D that have nothing to do with extraterrestrial issues or technology.” He described the allegations’ supporters as “a small group of interconnected believers and others with possibly less than honest intentions,” who promote a “whirlwind of tall tales, fabrication and secondhand or thirdhand retellings”.

In an interview with Peter Bergen, Kirkpatrick said that Grusch may have misinterpreted things or fallen under the influence of a core group of people. He characterized the situation as a “self licking ice cream cone,” where UFO true believers are carrying out a conspiracy to get the government involved in investigating aliens.

Media Reporting on Grusch’s Claims ðŸ”—

This section examines how the media has covered Grusch’s claims.

Connections to Studies Funded by Robert Bigelow ðŸ”—

Keith Kloor draws a connection between Grusch’s claims and studies funded by Robert Bigelow, noting specific references to “a football fieldâ€“sized UFO” in both.

Reporting on Psychiatric Treatment Received by Grusch ðŸ”—

Ken Klippenstein reported in The Intercept that Grusch was twice committed after incidents involving drunkenness and suicidal comments. Police records mentioned PTSD. Grusch was placed under an emergency custody order and transported to an emergency room. Grusch sued Loudoun County Sheriff Mike Chapman for releasing the information.

News Stories and Commentary ðŸ”—

Nick Pope, who previously ran the British Ministry of Defense “UFO Desk”, expressed doubt about confirming Grusch’s claims. Marina Koren wrote that the case fits a pattern of unprovable claims. Matt Laslo described the sympathetic hearing of Grusch’s claims by some members of Congress as an indication that “once-fringe notions have built-in fan bases in today’s Capitol”. Tucker Carlson publicized the claims. Tom Rogan was skeptical but opined that they should be further investigated.

Andrew Prokop wrote that skeptics question whether Grusch is repeating tall tales. Sean Thomas expressed confusion that others have tried to convince officials and the public that UFOs are worthy of serious considerations. Ross Douthat noted that one interpretation is that parts of the U.S. government see benefit in promoting belief in UFOs. Matt Stieb described Grusch’s claims as “crazy”.

Ezra Klein interviewed Leslie Kean, noting that reactions to her story about Grusch have been either to embrace it as definitive truth or dismiss it out of hand. Steven Greenstreet criticized Grusch for previously attending UFO conventions and associating with Jeremy Corbell and George Knapp.

The story received attention from multiple foreign mainstream news outlets.

Disinformation Campaign Allegations ðŸ”—

Grusch claimed that intentional disinformation was being promoted by the US government to cast doubt on the veracity of “non-human” UFO claims. Adam Gabbatt described Grusch’s position as “a common conspiracy trope in the UFO community”. Others have suggested that Grusch was given disinformation about aliens. Gareth Nicholson wrote that “the current UAP flap could be an attempt by the US military to engage in a disinformation campaign to disguise real aerospace breakthroughs or an attempt to flush out advanced technologies held by rivals such as Russia and China”.

item.description:
Pentagon UFO Videos ðŸ”—

This article discusses the widely publicized cockpit instrumentation display videos from US Navy fighter jets, often characterized as UFOs.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the videos, referencing historical UFO photographs and events. It details the initial incident on November 14, 2004, involving Commander David Fravor of the USS Nimitz Carrier Strike Group investigating radar indications of a possible target off the coast of southern California. The USS Princeton had been tracking unusual aircraft for two weeks prior to the incident. Fravor’s account of encountering a white, oval object hovering above an ocean disturbance is highlighted, as well as the observations of other pilots. It also mentions Lieutenant Commander Chad Underwood, who recorded the “FLIR” video and coined the term “Tic Tac” to describe the object. The section also mentions the 2014-2015 incidents involving fighter pilots associated with the USS Theodore Roosevelt carrier strike group operating off the East Coast of the United States, during which the GIMBAL and GOFAST videos were recorded.

Release of Videos ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the public release of the videos. The New York Times reported on the incidents and published the “FLIR” and “GIMBAL” videos in December 2017, while the Washington Post published the “GOFAST” video. Christopher Mellon, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence, provided the videos to the press. Luis Elizondo, the director of the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, resigned from the Pentagon in October 2017 to protest government secrecy. In September 2019, the Pentagon confirmed the videos were made by naval aviators. On April 27, 2020, the Pentagon formally released the three videos. In February 2020, the United States Navy confirmed that intelligence briefings have been provided to members of Congress.

2021 Release ðŸ”—

This section details the release of additional footage in 2021. In April 2021, the Pentagon confirmed the authenticity of a video taken by Navy personnel aboard USS Russell in 2019, showing a triangular object. Mick West suggested the image was the result of an optical effect called a bokeh. The Pentagon also confirmed photographs of objects described as “sphere”, “acorn” and “metallic blimp”. In May 2021, a second video recorded by Navy personnel aboard the USS Omaha on July 15, 2019, was confirmed and is under review by the UAP Task Force. The video purportedly shows a spherical object flying over the ocean. Mick West commented on the video, suggesting it could simply be a plane.

2023 Release ðŸ”—

This section covers the release of additional videos in 2023. In early 2023, an object was filmed by two MQ-9 drones in South Asia, initially believed to be anomalous but later identified as a commuter aircraft. On May 31, 2023, Sean M. Kirkpatrick shared an infrared video recorded in the western United States in 2021, which AARO concluded to be commercial aircraft. On April 19, 2023, the Pentagon released another video featuring MQ-9 drone footage from the Middle East depicting an unidentified aerial phenomenon resembling a small “metallic orb”. Sean M. Kirkpatrick briefed a Senate Armed Services subcommittee on the video, but stated they are unable to fully identify anything from the video.

Potential Explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores potential explanations for the aerial phenomena recorded in the videos. As of 2020, the Department of Defense characterizes the phenomena as “unidentified”. Skeptical explanations include instrument malfunction, human observational error, or common aircraft. Mick West cautioned that believers in “alien disclosure” are “encroaching on these real issues of UAPs”. Adam Frank speculated that the UFOs could be drones deployed by rivals like Russia and China. Thomas Bania speculated that they could be some form of electronic warfare fielded by China or Russia. The US Navy updated its reporting guidelines for unexplained aerial observations. Senator Marco Rubio expressed concern that the UFOs may be Chinese or Russian technology. Admiral Gary Roughead said that most assessments were inconclusive. Jeff Wise suggests advancements in electronic warfare could deceive sensors. In 2023, David Fravor testified under oath regarding the USS Nimitz sighting, stating that the technology was far superior to anything the US had.

June 2021 UFO Report ðŸ”—

This section discusses the preliminary report on UAPs released by the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) on June 25, 2021. The report came to no conclusion about what the UAPs were, citing a lack of sufficient data. Some UAPs appeared to exhibit unusual flight characteristics, including high velocity and maneuverability. The report indicated that the UAP recordings probably were of physical objects and proposed five possible categories of explanation: airborne clutter, natural atmospheric phenomena, US government or industry development technology, foreign craft, and an “Other” category. The report raised concerns about safety and security issues and indicated that investigation of the topic would continue.

FOI Request by The Black Vault ðŸ”—

This section details a Freedom of Information request made by The Black Vault for the release of more video footage. The government confirmed it had more footage but refused to release it, citing concerns for national security. Gregory Cason stated that the release of this information would harm national security.

In Popular Culture ðŸ”—

This section notes the videos’ appearance in the History Channel series Unidentified: Inside America’s UFO Investigation and an interview with Fravor on The Joe Rogan Experience.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics, including the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force, All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, Navy UFO patents, and the film The Phenomenon.

As of 2020, the Department of Defense characterizes the phenomena as “unidentified.” Widespread media attention has led to various theories, including pseudoscientific explanations such as ufology.

Skeptical explanations include instrument malfunction, human observational illusion, or common aircraft. Mick West cautioned that believers in “alien disclosure” are encroaching on real issues and that the recorded UFOs might be commercial airplanes or balloons distorted by infrared glare.

Astrophysicist Adam Frank speculated that the UFOs could be drones deployed by rivals like Russia and China. Astronomer Thomas Bania speculated that they could be electronic warfare technology.

The US Navy updated its guidelines for reporting unexplained aerial observations. A spokesman suggested that the increase in reported intrusions could be due to the rise in availability of unmanned aerial systems.

Senator Marco Rubio expressed concern that the UFOs may be Chinese or Russian technology. Retired Admiral Gary Roughead said that most assessments were inconclusive.

Adam Dodd and security expert Jack Weinstein say that neither China nor Russia presently have the capability to produce aircraft with such extraordinary capabilities.

Jeff Wise suggested that advancements in electronic warfare techniques could deceive sensors, resulting in false velocity and position information.

In 2023, David Fravor testified under oath that the technology they faced was far superior to anything they had.

June 2021 UFO report ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) preliminary report on UAPs released on June 25, 2021.

The report came to no conclusion about what the UAPs were, citing a lack of sufficient data. In a limited number of incidents, UAP appeared to exhibit unusual flight characteristics. Some of the UAPs appeared to move with no discernible means of propulsion.

The report indicated that, in most cases, the UAP recordings probably were of physical objects. The report proposed five possible categories of explanation: airborne clutter, natural atmospheric phenomena, US government or industry development technology, foreign craft, and an “Other” category.

The report raised concerns about safety and security issues and indicated that investigation of the topic would continue.

FOI request by The Black Vault ðŸ”—

This section discusses a Freedom of Information request made by The Black Vault for the release of more video footage.

In April 2020, The Black Vault made a Freedom of Information request to the US Navy. The government confirmed it had more footage but refused to release it, citing concerns for national security.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section notes the appearance of the videos in popular media.

The videos were featured in the 2019 History Channel series Unidentified: Inside America’s UFO Investigation. Episode 1361 of The Joe Rogan Experience featured the videos and interviewed Fravor.

item.title: 2007 Alderney UFO sighting
item.description:
2007 Alderney UFO sighting ðŸ”—

This article details the reported UFO sighting that occurred on April 23, 2007, over Alderney in the Channel Islands.

Accounts of the sighting ðŸ”—

This section introduces the event, mentioning that a pilot, Ray Bowyer, reported seeing unidentified flying objects. An air traffic controller confirmed that another pilot had reported a similar sighting. Passengers on Bowyer’s aircraft also reported seeing unusual lights. Possible explanations for the sighting, such as earthquake lights and sun dogs, are also mentioned.

Bowyer’s accounts ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the account of Ray Bowyer, the pilot who initially reported the sighting. It details his description of the object as a “cigar-shaped brilliant white light,” initially thought to be reflections from greenhouses. Bowyer’s estimates of the object’s size and distance evolved, eventually describing it as being the size of a Boeing 737, then later as large as five or six battleships or a reasonably large town. The section includes details from a recorded conversation between Bowyer and an air traffic controller, who reported only a faint radar contact. Bowyer’s actions, such as using binoculars to observe the light, and his report to the Civil Aviation Authority are also covered. The Ministry of Defence’s initial reluctance to investigate and subsequent release of information, including a statement from a second pilot, are mentioned.

Other witness accounts ðŸ”—

This section presents accounts from other witnesses to the event. Passengers on Bowyer’s aircraft reported seeing the light, with one describing it as “sunlight-colored” and another as “an orange light â€¦ like an elongated oval.” Patrick Patterson, a pilot from Blue Islands, also reported seeing a similar object in the same general location. The section also mentions an interpretation that the sighting was an atmospheric phenomenon.

Proposed explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores potential explanations for the UFO sighting. Bowyer rejected the idea that he saw an alien vessel, but considered the possibility of earthquake lights related to the earthquake in south-eastern England that occurred shortly after the sighting. A local astronomer, Michael Maunder, suggested that the sighting could be attributed to sun dogs, an optical phenomenon caused by the refraction of light through ice crystals. He noted that the weather conditions were favorable for sun dogs and that the reported lights were approximately 22 degrees from the sun, consistent with the appearance of sun dogs.

item.title: UFO reports and atomic sites
item.description:
Correlation between UFO reports and atomic sites ðŸ”—

This article explores the historical and statistical connections between reports of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) and locations associated with atomic technology, primarily in the United States. It examines how early speculation linked UFO sightings to atomic sites, the influence of the Cold War, and various incidents and studies that have fueled this correlation.

Background ðŸ”—

This section establishes the context for the link between UFO reports and atomic sites. It highlights the increased scrutiny of US airspace due to national security concerns in 1947, coinciding with increased media coverage of UFO reports. It notes that the development of atomic weapons and long-range vehicles meant that even a small number of adversarial overflights could have significant national security implications.

1940s weapons development ðŸ”—

This section details the development of atomic weapons by the US during World War II as part of the Manhattan Project. Key locations mentioned are Oak Ridge, Tennessee (uranium enrichment), Hanford, Washington (plutonium production), and Los Alamos, New Mexico (bomb design and construction). It also discusses the increased lethality and range of air power during the war and Japan’s deployment of intercontinental balloon bombs, one of which interfered with plutonium production at Hanford. The US’s Project Mogul, inspired by the Japanese balloons, aimed to detect Soviet atomic tests. The section also mentions German advancements in rockets, jet fighters, and bomber designs, which both the US and Soviet governments learned about and utilized after the war.

Increased scrutiny of US airspace ðŸ”—

This section explains how the possibility of a Soviet atomic attack led to increased surveillance of US airspace, particularly around atomic facilities. It mentions the development of the first intercontinental bomber, the Convair B-36 Peacemaker, which could reach the Soviet Union from American soil. Atomic sites were among the first locations in the US to operate radar, supported by visual spotters and fighter squadrons. The start of the Cold War in 1947 influenced media coverage of UFO reports, treating them as potential national security threats rather than folklore or tall tales.

Chronology ðŸ”—

This section presents a timeline of notable UFO incidents and their connection to atomic sites, starting in 1947.

Supposed flying discs allegedly break sound barrier ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Kenneth Arnold sighting in June 1947, where he reported seeing nine objects flying at supersonic speeds near Mount Rainier and Mount Adams in Washington state. The proximity of this sighting to the Hanford plutonium plant led to media speculation about a connection. The section also notes that the sound barrier was not officially broken until October 1947 by Chuck Yeager, and the Air Force initially denied the achievement.

Roswell and atomic weapons ðŸ”—

This section discusses the Roswell incident in July 1947, where debris was found on a ranch near Corona, New Mexico. The 509th at Roswell was the Army’s atomic bomb group. The initial explanation of a weather balloon was later questioned, and the Air Force eventually concluded the debris came from a Project Mogul balloon designed to detect Soviet atomic tests.

Public claims of link to atomic sites ðŸ”—

This section covers the public’s perception of a link between flying discs and atomic weaponry in 1947. It mentions headlines claiming a connection between “discs” and “atom products,” citing an unnamed scientist from the Manhattan Project who suggested experiments in atomic energy transmutation were responsible for the sightings. The Hanford works were also mentioned as a location with numerous UFO reports. Atomic scientists Harold Urey and David E. Lilienthal dismissed these claims as “gibberish.”

Mantell crash near Oak Ridge ðŸ”—

This section details the Mantell incident in January 1948, where Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a pilot from Fort Knox, Kentucky, crashed while pursuing a UFO near Oak Ridge, Tennessee. The Air Force later attributed the UFO to a Skyhook balloon, a classified project.

Green Fireballs near Hanford ðŸ”—

This section discusses reports of green fireballs near Hanford, Washington, starting in December 1948. It mentions Lincoln LaPaz’s investigation of these reports and the issuance of orders to fire on potentially hostile aircraft over Hanford and Oak Ridge. The section also notes UFO reports over Hanford and Oak Ridge during the early days of the Korean War and a 1952 Life Magazine article reporting unusual radar returns near an atomic installation.

Contactees and nuclear war ðŸ”—

This section discusses the theme of nuclear war in UFO culture. The 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still featured a benevolent spaceman warning about atomic weapons. George Adamski began claiming contact with “space brothers” concerned about atomic weapons.

Big Sur missile test ðŸ”—

This section describes a reported UFO incident during a 1964 Air Force missile test near Big Sur, California. Robert Jacobs, who oversaw the team, claimed a UFO interfered with the test. Kingston George, the project engineer, argued the team had actually recorded the release of decoy warheads and chaff.

Malmstrom missile malfunction ðŸ”—

This section discusses UFO reports over a missile complex in March 1967 during a routine malfunction. Retired Air Force personnel later claimed the weapons failure was caused by a UFO.

Hynek suggests atomic link ðŸ”—

This section notes that astronomer J. Allen Hynek, initially hired by the Air Force to debunk UFO reports, began speculating in 1968 that UFOs might be related to an unknown phenomenon connected to nuclear energy.

Rendelsham ðŸ”—

This section describes the Rendlesham Forest incident in December 1980, a series of reported sightings of unexplained lights near RAF Woodbridge in England, which was used by the United States Air Force (USAF). USAF personnel, including Lieutenant Colonel Charles I. Halt, claimed to see things they described as a UFO.

21st century ðŸ”—

This section covers more recent developments, including a legend that the 1945 Trinity atomic bomb test brought down an alien spacecraft. It mentions Robert Hastings’ book UFOs & Nukes: Extraordinary Encounters at Nuclear Weapons Sites and claims by former AATIP director Luis Elizondo and former U.S. Air Force personnel that UAPs have interfered with nuclear capabilities. It also notes reports of UFOs interfering with other major powers’ nuclear weapons systems. The section mentions the U.S. National Defense Authorization Act requesting more information on UAP incidents associated with military nuclear assets and claims by Robert L. Salas and Robert Hastings of alien abduction. Finally, it mentions that the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission will raise the issue of UAP with its United States counterpart.

Statistical studies ðŸ”—

This section examines the statistical evidence for a correlation between UFO reports and atomic sites, considering the possibility of observational bias.

It introduces the concept of the “streetlight effect,” where observations are more likely to be reported where observations are most likely to occur. Mainstream experts argue that increased scrutiny of airspace around strategically important facilities explains the correlation.

The section mentions a rudimentary spatial analysis conducted by Air Force officers in the 1950s, which found that UFOs were seen more frequently around areas vital to US defense, such as Los Alamos-Albuquerque, Oak Ridge, and White Sands Proving Ground.

A 2015 study of UFO reports in France concluded that there was a statistically significant link between nuclear activities and unexplained UFO reports.

A 2021 document from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence suggested that clustering of UFO reports around US training and testing grounds might be due to “collection bias as a result of focused attention.”

A 2023 study examined a National UFO Reporting Center dataset and found that UFO reports are more frequent in areas with darker nighttime skies and “wide-open spaces.” Additionally, analysis suggested that proximity to airports and military installations was linked to increased UFO reports.

item.title: Travis Walton incident
item.description:
The Travis Walton Incident ðŸ”—

The Travis Walton incident is an alleged alien abduction that occurred on November 5, 1975, involving American forestry worker Travis Walton in the Apacheâ€“Sitgreaves National Forests near Heber, Arizona. The incident is widely considered a hoax.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the alleged abduction, noting that in the early 1970s, the National Enquirer tabloid offered a substantial prize for proof of extraterrestrial visitors, which may have motivated the hoax.

Travis Walton and the Turkey Springs forestry job ðŸ”—

This section details the circumstances surrounding Travis Walton’s employment and the forestry contract. Key points include:

  • Location: The forestry job was located in Turkey Springs, about 12 miles south of Heber, Arizona. The crew lived in Snowflake, 30 miles away.
  • People: Travis Walton, his brother Duane, and crew chief Michael H. Rogers are central figures.
  • Financial Motive: Rogers’s forestry contract was behind schedule, potentially leading to financial penalties. The section notes that Walton had a prior criminal record.
  • Contract Details: The Turkey Springs job involved thinning 1,277 acres by August 1975, later extended to November 10. Failure to complete the job could result in a $2,500 penalty.

Barney Hill and NBC’s The UFO Incident ðŸ”—

This section highlights the potential influence of the 1975 NBC television movie The UFO Incident, which dramatized the alleged abduction of Barney and Betty Hill. It suggests that the film may have inspired Walton and Rogers to fabricate their own abduction story. Skeptics and psychologists are quoted arguing that the film could have motivated someone to claim an abduction for attention. It also mentions that Travis Walton told his mother not to worry if he were ever abducted by aliens because he would return safe and sound.

Incident ðŸ”—

This section outlines the events of November 5, 1975, when Michael H. Rogers reported Travis Walton missing. The crew claimed they saw a lit object near the roadway, Walton approached it, and was struck by a light. The crew drove away in fear and returned to find Walton and the object gone. The police were notified, and a search was initiated. Deputy Kenneth Coplan noted the calm reaction of Walton’s mother to the news of his disappearance.

Missing person investigation ðŸ”—

This section details the search efforts and initial investigation following Walton’s disappearance. Key points include:

  • Search Party: A search party of nearly 50 people scoured the Turkey Springs area without success.
  • Family’s Reaction: Law enforcement were surprised by the calm reaction of Travis’s mother, who believed he was no longer on Earth.
  • UFO Interest: It was revealed that Travis, Duane, and their mother were interested in UFOs.
  • Polygraph Tests: Rogers and the crew underwent polygraph examinations to determine if they had harmed Walton. Five were deemed truthful, while one was inconclusive.
  • Act of God Clause: Rogers discussed the Forestry contract and the potential for an “Act of God” clause to excuse the delay.

Walton returns ðŸ”—

This section describes Walton’s reappearance and subsequent events. Key points include:

  • Return: Walton called his sister’s home from a payphone in Heber, Arizona, on November 12, shortly after midnight.
  • Deputy Glen Flake: Deputy Flake witnessed Duane Walton transferring fuel from one car to another after having forgotten to purchase gas before local stations closed. Flake did not reveal that they knew Travis had returned home, and Duane did not tell the deputy that Travis had been found.
  • Medical Attention: Duane sought medical attention for Travis, consulting with a hypnotherapist and later two medical doctors who were also amateur UFO investigators.
  • Sheriff Gillespie: Sheriff Gillespie insisted on interviewing Travis, but Duane and Travis demanded that the interview not be recorded.
  • National Enquirer: The National Enquirer provided a suite at the Sheraton Inn in Scottsdale in exchange for exclusive access to Walton and his story.
  • Polygraph Test: Travis skipped a polygraph interview with police, but was later interviewed by Jack McCarthy a free-lance polygraph examiner arranged by a UFO group and the Enquirer. McCarthy concluded that Travis was engaged in a “gross deception”.
  • Television Interview: Walton appeared on Phoenix television, claiming he lost consciousness and awoke in a hospital-like room with short, bald creatures.

Publicity and popular culture ðŸ”—

This section covers the media attention and cultural impact of the Walton incident. Key points include:

  • National Enquirer Prize: The National Enquirer awarded Walton and his co-workers a $5,000 prize for “best UFO case of the year.”
  • Skepticism: Skeptics, including Philip J. Klass, viewed the story as a hoax for financial gain.
  • Book and Film: Walton wrote The Walton Experience in 1978, which was adapted into the 1993 film Fire in the Sky.
  • Media Appearances: Walton has appeared at UFO conventions and on television, including The Moment of Truth and the Joe Rogan Experience podcast.

Rogers-Walton dispute of 2021 ðŸ”—

This section details a public dispute between Mike Rogers and Travis Walton in 2021. Rogers initially recanted his status as a witness to the abduction, claiming it was a hoax, but later reconciled with Walton and retracted his confession.

Modern views ðŸ”—

This section presents contemporary perspectives on the Walton incident.

Waltons as UFO buffs and pranksters ðŸ”—

This section highlights the Walton family’s interest in UFOs and their reputation for pranks. It suggests that the incident may have been planned by Travis Walton and Mike Rogers. Crew member Steve Pierce expressed suspicion that the incident had been a hoax.

National Enquirer misrepresented polygraph results ðŸ”—

This section notes that the National Enquirer publicized the opinion of a private polygraph examiner who reported the witnesses as being truthful, but omitted all mention of Walton’s prior polygraph examiner who concluded Walton was being “grossly deceptive”.

Contrast with alien abduction syndrome ðŸ”—

This section contrasts Walton’s account with typical alien abduction narratives, noting that Walton didn’t report paralysis, recovered memories, or other common elements.

Possible role of fire lookout tower ðŸ”—

This section presents Robert Sheaffer’s hypothesis that Rogers and the Waltons used a nearby fire lookout tower to create the illusion of a UFO. Sheaffer suggests that Travis walked towards the tower, which was brightly lit, and an accomplice illuminated him with a spotlight.

See also ðŸ”—

This section lists related topics, including lists of reported UFO sightings and solved missing person cases.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travis_Walton_UFO_incident

item.title: Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting
item.description:
Alleged 1947 Sighting in Washington, US: Kenneth Arnold UFO Sighting ðŸ”—

This article discusses the alleged UFO sighting by private pilot Kenneth Arnold on June 24, 1947, near Mount Rainier, Washington. This sighting is considered a seminal event in the modern history of UFOs, as it garnered nationwide news coverage and popularized the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disc.”

Sighting ðŸ”—

On June 24, 1947, Kenneth Arnold, while flying from Chehalis to Yakima, Washington, detoured to search for a crashed U.S. Marine Corps C-46 transport plane near Mount Rainier. Near Mineral, Washington, at approximately 9,200 feet, Arnold observed nine shiny objects flying in formation past Mount Rainier. He estimated their speed to be over 1,200 miles per hour. Arnold described the objects as thin, flat, and convex, with one being crescent-shaped. He likened their movement to saucers skipping on water. The objects traveled from Mount Rainier to Mount Adams in 1 minute and 42 seconds.

Arnold Shares the Story ðŸ”—

After landing in Yakima, Arnold shared his experience with fellow pilots. He was interviewed by reporters from the East Oregonian in Pendleton, Oregon, the next day. The reporters found Arnold to be a credible witness. Arnold expressed his desire to speak with the FBI due to the widespread attention and skepticism surrounding his account.

Corroboration ðŸ”—

Several other individuals reported similar sightings around the same time as Arnold. L.G. Bernier of Richland, Washington, saw three objects flying towards Mount Rainier about half an hour before Arnold’s sighting. Ethel Wheelhouse in Yakima, Washington, also reported seeing flying discs moving at high speeds. A member of the Washington State forest service reported seeing flashes over Mount Rainier at the same time as Arnold’s sighting. Ten days later, a United Airlines crew over Idaho also spotted similar objects.

Arnold Talks of Possible Non-Earthly Origins ðŸ”—

In early July 1947, Arnold discussed the possibility of extraterrestrial origins for the objects. He mentioned receiving fan mail with various interpretations, including visitations from another planet. Arnold expressed his hope that the devices were U.S. Army creations but also stated that if the government knew anything, the public should be informed. He also noted the objects’ abrupt turns, suggesting they might be controlled from elsewhere, possibly another planet.

Publicity and Origins of Term “Flying Saucer” ðŸ”—

Arnold’s account received widespread media coverage, appearing in numerous U.S. and Canadian newspapers. The terms “flying saucer” and “flying disc” became popular descriptors for UFOs following the sighting. While the exact origin of the terms is debated, it’s believed they emerged from early news stories about Arnold’s experience.

The Term Appears ðŸ”—

Newspapers began using the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disc” to describe the objects starting on June 26 and 27. The Arnold sighting is credited with popularizing these terms.

Bequette Interview ðŸ”—

Years later, Arnold claimed he told Bill Bequette that the objects “flew erratic, like a saucer if you skip it across the water,” emphasizing the motion rather than the shape. Bequette’s initial articles described the objects as “saucer-like” and their motion as “like fish flipping in the sun.”

Military Investigation of Arnold Story ðŸ”—

The first investigation of Arnold’s claims was conducted by Lt. Frank Brown and Capt. William Davidson of Hamilton Field, California, on July 12. They concluded that Arnold likely saw what he reported. However, First Lt. Hal L. Eustace of the Army Air Corps described Arnold as “excitable” and his report as a “silly season episode.” The Army Air Force’s official conclusion was that the objects were due to a mirage. AAF intelligence, with FBI assistance, initiated a secret investigation of the best sightings, including Arnold’s. This led to the formation of Project Sign at the end of 1947, the first publicly acknowledged USAF UFO investigation.

Widespread UFO Reports After Arnold Sighting ðŸ”—

In the weeks following Arnold’s sighting, numerous reports of similar objects flooded in from the U.S. and around the world.

Skeptical Explanations ðŸ”—

Officials at McChord Army Air Field suggested the objects could have been fast P-80 jets. Lieutenant Colonel Harry R. Turner of the White Sands Proving Ground also stated that Arnold’s sighting was consistent with jet airplanes. Steuart Campbell proposed that the objects were mirages of snow-capped peaks in the Cascade Range. Philip J. Klass argued that Arnold might have misidentified meteors. James Easton suggested that Arnold may have misidentified pelicans.

Donald Menzel’s Explanations ðŸ”—

Donald Menzel, a Harvard astronomer and UFO debunker, offered several explanations for Arnold’s sighting, including clouds of snow, orographic clouds, wave clouds, and spots of water on his airplane’s windows.

item.title: Psychosocial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Psychosocial Hypothesis in Ufology ðŸ”—

The psychosocial hypothesis (PSH) in ufology posits that psychological and social factors best explain some UFO reports. It contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH). This perspective is favored by UFO researchers in the UK, including David Clarke and Hilary Evans, and in France, following Michel Monnerie’s 1977 book. PSH researchers distinguish themselves from debunkers by maintaining a serious, albeit skeptical, interest in UFOs. The hypothesis suggests that mundane explanations combined with emotional climates distort perceptions, and that claims of contact with extraterrestrials from uninhabitable planets point to psychological processes like dreams and hallucinations.

Origin ðŸ”—

The term “psychosocial hypothesis” gained prominence in English UFO literature in 1984, with Jacques Scornaux and Peter Rogerson’s article in Magonia. Scornaux’s use of the term originated from French UFO controversies sparked by Michel Monnerie’s challenge to the ETH. Rogerson’s adoption of the term marked a shift from paranormal explanations to normal psychological processes influenced by cultural myths and social conditioning. Writers for Magonia had been exploring alternatives to the ETH since 1968, noting the failure of the ETH to account for high strangeness cases. Roger Sandell’s research on a 1905 Welsh UFO wave led him to believe that UFO reports were part of a larger complex of ghost stories and religious visions. Peter Rogerson advocated for a search for historical antecedents of UFO rumors and the social factors driving UFO flaps and social panics, noting a relationship between UFO waves and times of radical social change.

Science Fiction Aspects of the UFO Mythos ðŸ”—

Bertrand MÃ©heust’s discovery of parallels between UFO experience narratives and pre-1947 science fiction literature led to a study of the science fiction aspects of UFO mythology. MÃ©heust found numerous parallels, including wondrous effects and humanoid motives. Michel Monnerie integrated Meheust’s study into his historical critique of UFO mythology. Michel Meurger expanded Meheust’s thesis into a compendium of parallels. Jacques Vallee noted electromagnetic effects associated with UFOs in earlier fiction. Researchers have explored the cultural back-stories to various alien types, including Grays, insectoids, and reptoids. Other studies explore science fictional saucer esoterica along psychosocial and historical lines.

The Saucer Rumor ðŸ”—

The mystery of why flying saucers are the dominant shape in UFO reports was addressed by Martin Kottmeyer, who discovered that Kenneth Arnold’s initial sighting in 1947 was misinterpreted. Arnold’s description of the objects’ motion, rather than their shape, led to the “flying saucer” label. This mistake shaped the UFO phenomenon for decades, influencing film imagery, saucer photography, UFO illustration, contactee tales, and abduction experiences. Kottmeyer’s findings, first reported in 1988, suggest a cultural origin for the flying saucer phenomenon. The principal counterargument is that flying saucers were seen before Kenneth Arnold’s story, but Kottmeyer argues that the dominance of the saucer shape after 1947 is the key issue.

Flaps of Flying Phantoms ðŸ”—

Early researchers attempted to correlate UFO flaps with Mars’ proximity, but these predictions failed. British researchers shifted focus to pre-1947 “waves,” examining social, religious, political, and scientific backgrounds. Roger Sandell’s work on a 1905 Welsh UFO outbreak revealed odd facets and high strangeness material. Nigel Watson reported on a 1909 panic involving German airships spying on Britain. Phantom airship flaps were catalogued from various locations, involving cigar-shaped craft and rumors of foreign spies. By the 1930s, phantom airships were replaced by phantom aeroplanes. Researchers have experimented with variations in these explanations, such as the 1905 Wales flap occurring during a time of social change. Researchers generally reject explanations involving mass hysteria, preferring to discuss flaps as collective delusions maintained by rumor and gossip.

The Modern Myth of Jung ðŸ”—

Carl Gustav Jung’s essay Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies is considered a foundational work for the PSH. Jung’s use of synchronicity has also led some to see him as a proponent of paranormal explanations. While Jung acknowledged the possibility of some UFOs being physical objects, he clarified that he was uncommitted on the issue of their reality. He expressed concern that news affirming the existence of UFOs was more welcome than skepticism.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychosocial_hypothesis

item.title: Malmstrom UFO incident
item.description:
Malmstrom UFO Incident ðŸ”—

This article discusses the alleged Malmstrom UFO incident, focusing on claims that a UFO sighting was connected to a weapons failure at a nuclear missile complex in Montana in 1967. It presents claims made by retired Air Force personnel, skeptical counterarguments, and the incident’s coverage in media.

1967 Missile Complex Malfunction ðŸ”—

This section details the 1967 incident at the Echo Flight missile complex, located between Hilger and Winifred, Montana, and operated by personnel from Malmstrom Air Force Base. On March 16, 1967, all sites in Echo Flight experienced a shutdown with “No-Go” indications, causing all launch facilities to lose strategic alert nearly simultaneously. An Air Force report mentioned rumors of UFOs around the area but stated they were disproven. A Mobile Strike Team reported no unusual activity or sightings. The malfunction, termed the “Echo Flight Incident,” was resolved within a day by maintenance crews.

Public Claims by Robert Salas ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the claims made by Robert Salas, a 26-year-old Air Force Lieutenant at the time of the 1967 malfunction. In a 1996 Great Falls Tribune article, Salas recounted how a security guard reported flying objects performing strange maneuvers and a glowing red object hovering above the front gate. Shortly after, the complex’s ten Minuteman nuclear missiles went offline. Salas emphasized he was not a “UFO junkie” and sought answers to the mystery.

Promotion in Media ðŸ”—

This section outlines the media coverage of the Malmstrom UFO incident. It notes coverage in regional papers starting in 2000, including the Missoula Independent in 2001 and 2002. Air Force documents related to the incident were released under the Freedom of Information Act. Robert Salas authored Faded Giant in 2005, speculating about a government cover-up to exploit extraterrestrial technology. In 2008, UFO author Robert Hastings discussed the incident in his book UFOs and Nukes, which Salas defended. Salas appeared at the National Press Club in 2010 with other UFO speakers and authored Unidentified: The UFO Phenomenon in 2014 and UAPs and the Nuclear Puzzle in 2023. The Great Falls Tribune marked the event’s 50th anniversary in 2017.

Skeptical Views ðŸ”—

This section presents skeptical perspectives on the Malmstrom UFO incident. Science writer Mick West argues that the military investigated the incident and found no connection to UFO sightings, attributing the story’s persistence to Salas’s promotional efforts. Brian Dunning points out discrepancies between Salas’s memories and records from the 341st Strategic Missile Wing, suggesting the missile restart was due to a commonplace power failure and unrelated to later UFO reports. Michael Shermer, appearing with Salas on CNN, suggested that people can be unreliable observers and that extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. Robert Sheaffer suggests the UFO sighting was likely Mars and unrelated to the missile malfunction.

item.description:
UFO (1956 film) ðŸ”—

A 1956 American semi-documentary film that explores the development of the UFO phenomenon in the United States. It is noted for its use of documentary clips that have been featured in other UFO-related media.

Origins and plot ðŸ”—

In 1952, Hollywood producer Clarence Greene, after witnessing an unusual aerial object, contacted US Air Force public information officer Albert M. Chop. Intrigued, Greene decided to create a documentary about UFOs, using film footage provided by Chop. The film begins in 1947, covering early UFO sightings like the Kenneth Arnold sighting, the Mantell UFO incident, and the Gorman Dogfight. It follows the evolution of UFOs as a cultural fad and a concern for the US Air Force, including the history of Project Sign. The film then focuses on Albert M. Chop, who is assigned as the public information officer at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio. Chop initially debunks UFOs but gradually changes his views, believing they are unknown aircraft, possibly extraterrestrial. By 1952, Chop is in Washington, D.C., as the press spokesman for Project Blue Book. The documentary analyzes the Mariana UFO Incident of 1950 and the 1952 UFO film taken near the Great Salt Lake in Utah by Delbert Newhouse. The film concludes with the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident, where Chop played a central role, ultimately stating his belief that UFOs are a real, physical phenomenon of unknown origin.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes Willis Sperry, Nicholas Mariana, Delbert Newhouse, Wendell Swanson, and U.S. Air Force General John A. Samford as themselves. Tom Towers plays Albert M. (Al) Chop, Floyd Burton plays Major Dewey Fournet, Gene Coughlan plays an editor from the Dayton Daily News, Bert Freed plays a Colonel, Stan Gordon plays a reporter, Marie Kenna plays Mrs. Albert Chop, Harry Morgan provides voices, Robert Phillips plays Captain Edward Ruppelt, William Solomon plays a German scientist, and Olan Soule is a narrator.

Trivia ðŸ”—

Actor Harry Morgan, known for his roles in M*A*S*H and Dragnet 1967, voices the pilot of “Air Force 216” and “Red Dog One” during key scenes, including the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident. Morgan’s Dragnet 1967 co-star Jack Webb produced and narrated the 1978 television series Project U.F.O., which recreated Project Bluebook.

Lists similar media, including the book The Report On Unidentified Flying Objects (1956), the film UFOs: Past, Present, and Future (1976), and the TV broadcast UFO Cover Up? Live (1988).

Lists the references used in the article, including articles from the Los Angeles Times, Turner Classic Movies, Christian Science Monitor, The Washington Post and Times-Herald, and New York Times.
