The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters in over 43 countries and all 50 US states. MUFON aims to investigate UFO sightings and provide information to the public.

History ðŸ”—

MUFON was originally established as the Midwest UFO Network on May 31, 1969, in Quincy, Illinois, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., John F. Schuessler, and others. It was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973 due to its expansion. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation ðŸ”—

Headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, MUFON has chapters throughout the U.S. and internationally. It hosts an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution for training UFO investigators. The organization has over 500 field investigators who investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft.

Criticism ðŸ”—

Pseudoscience ðŸ”—

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience, including topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, and human-ET hybrids. Critics argue that MUFON’s investigations lack scientific rigor and that its researchers are often not scientists.

item.title: Aurora, Texas, UFO incident
item.description:
Aurora, Texas, UFO Incident ðŸ”—

This article details the alleged UFO crash that reportedly occurred on April 17, 1897, near Aurora, Texas. Locals claimed a UFO crashed on a farm, resulting in the death of its pilot, an alien being. The pilot was purportedly buried in the Aurora Cemetery.

The Incident as Reported ðŸ”—

This section recounts the details of the incident as reported in the Dallas Morning News article written by S.E. Haydon. The article describes how a UFO crashed into a windmill on Judge J.S. Proctor’s property. The pilot, described as “not of this world,” was speculated to be from Mars by an Army Signal Service officer named T.J. Weems. The pilot was buried with Christian rites in the Aurora Cemetery, which now has a Texas Historical Commission marker mentioning the incident. The wreckage was reportedly dumped into a well on the property. Mr. Brawley Oates, who later purchased the property, sealed the well after developing severe arthritis, which he attributed to contamination from the wreckage.

Hoax Theory ðŸ”—

This section presents the theory that the Aurora incident was a hoax. It cites a 1980 Time magazine interview with Etta Pegues, an Aurora resident, who claimed that S.E. Haydon fabricated the story to revive the town’s economy after the railroad bypassed it. Pegues also claimed that Judge Proctor never had a windmill on his property, a statement that was later challenged. Paranormal researcher Jerry Drake challenged the finding that the well was designed for use with a windmill.

Investigations ðŸ”—

This section outlines the various investigations into the Aurora incident, including reports by KDFW, UFO Files, and UFO Hunters.

KDFW Report ðŸ”—

In 1998, KDFW aired a report featuring interviews with Jim Marrs and other locals who believed something crashed in Aurora. The report found no conclusive evidence of extraterrestrial life or technology.

UFO Files Investigation ðŸ”—

The UFO Files episode, “Texas’ Roswell,” featured a 1973 investigation led by Bill Case of the Dallas Times Herald and MUFON. The investigation uncovered two new eyewitnesses: Mary Evans, who spoke of her parents’ visit to the crash site and the discovery of the alien body, and Charlie Stephens, who saw the airship trailing smoke. MUFON investigated the Aurora Cemetery and found a grave marker that appeared to depict a flying saucer. They requested permission to exhume the site but were denied. The marker later disappeared, and metal readings from the grave vanished. The report concluded that the evidence was inconclusive.

UFO Hunters Investigation ðŸ”—

The UFO Hunters episode, “First Contact,” featured Tim Oates, grandson of Brawley Oates, allowing investigators to unseal the well on his property. Water samples showed high levels of aluminum, but the well contained no significant debris. The remains of a windmill base were found near the well site. Ground-penetrating radar revealed an unmarked grave in the cemetery near other 1890s graves. The condition of the grave was badly deteriorated, and the radar could not conclusively prove what type of remains existed. The landowner provided pieces of metal containing mostly aluminum and an unknown element.

In Popular Culture ðŸ”—

This section notes the dramatization of the incident in the 1986 film The Aurora Encounter and its discussion in Ancient Aliens. It also mentions an independent short movie titled Aurora by Thomas Negovan and Aaron Shaps, which combines the incident with the Nazi conspiracy theory of Die Glocke. The Firesign Theatre’s comedy LP Everything You Know Is Wrong satirizes the incident.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics, including “List of reported UFO sightings” and “Mystery airship.”

item.title: Roswell incident
item.description:
UFO Legend Caused by 1947 Balloon Crash: Roswell Incident ðŸ”—

The Roswell incident is a cornerstone of UFO lore, stemming from the recovery of debris near Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. Initially reported as a “flying disc” capture, the U.S. Army quickly retracted the statement, claiming it was a weather balloon. This event, coupled with subsequent government explanations and retractions, fueled decades of conspiracy theories alleging a cover-up of extraterrestrial contact.

1947 Military Balloon Crash ðŸ”—

This section details the initial event and its immediate aftermath. In 1947, rancher W.W. “Mac” Brazel discovered debris on his property near Corona, New Mexico. The debris consisted of tinfoil, rubber, tape, and wooden beams. Unaware of the ongoing “flying disc craze,” Brazel initially didn’t connect the debris to UFOs. However, after visiting Corona, his uncle suggested it could be from a “flying disk.” Brazel reported the findings to Sheriff George Wilcox, who contacted Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF).

RAAF sent Major Jesse Marcel and Captain Sheridan Cavitt to investigate. A press release issued by public information officer Walter Haut announced the military’s recovery of a “flying disc.” This announcement made international headlines but was quickly retracted. General Roger Ramey and weather officer Irving Newton identified the material as a weather balloon at a press conference.

UFO Conspiracy Theories (1947â€“1978) ðŸ”—

This section explores the period between the initial incident and the rise of modern Roswell conspiracy theories. The Roswell debris retrieval faded from public attention for three decades. However, belief in government UFO cover-ups grew, fueled by hoaxes and legends of crashed spaceships and alien bodies in New Mexico. The Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax introduced the idea of recovered alien bodies, which later became associated with Roswell. The concept of “Hangar 18,” a fictional location at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, emerged as a storage site for alien craft and bodies.

Roswell Conspiracy Theories (1978â€“1994) ðŸ”—

This section details the resurgence of interest in Roswell and the development of modern conspiracy theories. In 1978, ufologist Stanton Friedman interviewed Jesse Marcel, who stated that the “weather balloon” explanation was a cover story and that he believed the debris was extraterrestrial. This interview, along with subsequent media attention, reignited interest in the Roswell incident.

The 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and Bill Moore popularized Marcel’s account and added the claim of alien bodies found on the Plains of San Agustin. The book also connected Marcel’s account to Lydia Sleppy, a former teletype operator who claimed she was ordered to stop transmitting a story about crashed saucer wreckage.

The Majestic 12 hoax, involving faked government documents, emerged in the 1980s, further fueling conspiracy theories. Glenn Dennis, a former mortician, provided an account of extraterrestrial corpses, which was endorsed by prominent Roswell ufologists.

Competing accounts of the Roswell incident led to a schism among ufologists in the early 1990s. UFO Crash at Roswell by Kevin Randle and Donald Schmitt added testimony from new witnesses. Crash at Corona by Stanton Friedman and Don Berliner introduced the idea of two crashed saucers and eight aliens. The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell by Randle and Schmitt proposed a new crash site and a different group of archaeologists.

Air Force Response ðŸ”—

This section outlines the official government response to the growing Roswell conspiracy theories. Under pressure from New Mexico congressman Steven Schiff and the General Accounting Office (GAO), the Air Force published reports in the mid-1990s. The initial 1994 report admitted that the weather balloon explanation was a cover story for Project Mogul, a military surveillance program. The 1995 report, The Roswell Report: Fact vs. Fiction in the New Mexico Desert, supported this with documentation that narrowed the cause of the debris to a specific Mogul balloon train. The 1997 report, The Roswell Report: Case Closed, detailed how eyewitness accounts of military personnel loading aliens into “body bags” matched the Air Force’s procedures for retrieving parachute test dummies.

Later Theories and Hoaxes (1994â€“Present) ðŸ”—

This section covers the continued development of Roswell theories and hoaxes in recent decades. Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, a pseudo-documentary, played a major role in shaping popular opinion of Roswell. The film centered around Ray Santilli’s hoaxed footage of an alien autopsy.

In 1997, retired army intelligence officer Philip J. Corso released The Day After Roswell, alleging that he was shown a nonhuman body and helped oversee a project to reverse engineer recovered crash debris.

Other theories include Annie Jacobsen’s Area 51: An Uncensored History of America’s Top Secret Military Base, which featured a claim that Nazi doctor Josef Mengele was recruited by Soviet leader Joseph Stalin to produce “grotesque, child-size aviators.”

Explanations ðŸ”—

This section presents the explanations for the Roswell incident, focusing on Project Mogul and anthropomorphic dummies. The Air Force reports identified Project Mogul as the source of the 1947 debris and concluded that other alien crash accounts were likely misidentified military programs or accidents. The 1997 Air Force report concluded that the alleged “bodies” reported by later eyewitnesses came from memories of accidents involving military casualties and memories of the recovery of anthropomorphic dummies.

Cultural Impact ðŸ”—

This section explores the impact of the Roswell incident on tourism, commercialization, and popular fiction. Roswell’s tourism industry is based on ufology museums and businesses, as well as alien-themed iconography. A yearly UFO festival has been held since 1995.

The incident has been depicted in numerous films and television shows, including Hangar 18, Independence Day, The X-Files, and Roswell.

Widespread speculation of a cover-up led to United States presidents being questioned about the Roswell incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_UFO_incident

Major Jesse Marcel and Captain Sheridan Cavitt were assigned to gather the material. On July 8, RAAF public information officer Walter Haut issued a press release stating that the military had recovered a “flying disc” near Roswell.

The section also describes the press conference where General Roger Ramey, Colonel Thomas DuBose, and weather officer Irving Newton identified the material as pieces of a weather balloon.

Hangar 18 ðŸ”—

This section discusses “Hangar 18,” a non-existent location that many later conspiracy theories allege housed extraterrestrial craft or bodies recovered from Roswell. The tabloid National Enquirer brought large-scale attention to the Marcel story the following February.

This section focuses on the first Roswell conspiracy book, The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and Bill Moore, released in October 1980. The book argues that an extraterrestrial craft was flying over the New Mexico desert to observe nuclear weapons activity when a lightning strike killed the alien crew. It alleges that, after recovering the crashed alien technology, the US government engaged in a cover-up to prevent mass panic.

Majestic 12 Hoax ðŸ”—

This section discusses Majestic 12, the purported organization behind faked government documents delivered anonymously to multiple ufologists in the 1980s. The anonymously delivered documents detailed the creation of a likely fictitious Majestic 12 group formed to handle Roswell debris.

This section introduces Glenn Dennis, a former mortician who provided an account of extraterrestrial corpses endorsed by prominent Roswell ufologists. This section discusses Stanton Friedman’s book, Crash at Corona, co-authored with Don Berliner, released in 1992. The book introduced new “witnesses” and added to the narrative by doubling the number of flying saucers to two, and the number of aliens to eight.

This section focuses on Randle and Schmitt’s 1994 book, The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell, which claimed a cargo plane delivered alien bodies to Dwight D. Eisenhower. The book abandoned the Barnett crash site on the Plains of San Agustin and proposed a new crash site 35 miles north of Roswell.

item.title: Investigation of UFO reports by the United States government
item.description:
UFO Investigations by the United States ðŸ”—

This article provides an overview of the history of UFO investigations conducted by the United States government, from the late 1940s to the present day. It notes that despite decades of investigation, no evidence of UFOs with extraordinary origins has been found, attributing reported sightings to natural phenomena, human technology, misinterpretations, delusions, or hoaxes.

Historical Precedents ðŸ”—

This section lists events that preceded the formal UFO investigations by the US government. These include the mystery airship sightings, ghost rockets, the Kenneth Arnold sighting, and the 1947 UFO craze.

Time Period ðŸ”—

This section simply states the time period covered by the article: 1947 to the present.

Project or Team Leaders ðŸ”—

This section identifies key individuals who led various US government UFO investigation projects and teams. These include:

  • Edward Ruppelt: Leader of Project Blue Book.
  • Hector Quintanilla: Also a leader of Project Blue Book.
  • Edward Condon: Leader of the Condon Committee.
  • David Spergel: Leader of NASA’s UAP study team.
  • Sean Kirkpatrick: Leader of the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO).

Key Events ðŸ”—

This section outlines significant events in the history of US government UFO investigations:

  • 1947: Air Force order issued to start UFO study.
  • 1948: Project Sign initiated.
  • 1949: Project Grudge replaced Project Sign.
  • 1952â€“1969: Project Blue Book replaced Project Grudge.
  • 1953: Robertson Panel convened.
  • 1966: Congressional hearing on UFOs.
  • 1968: Condon Committee formed.
  • 1969: Congressional hearing on UFOs.
  • 1994â€“1997: Air Force releases official reports on the Roswell incident.
  • 2007â€“2017: Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program (AATIP) operated (dates disputed).
  • 2017â€“2022: Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force (UAPTF) replaced AATIP.
  • 2022: Congressional hearing on UAPs.
  • 2022â€“present: NASA’s UAP study team established.
  • 2022â€“present: AARO replaced UAPTF.
  • 2023: Congressional hearing on UAPs featuring David Grusch’s whistleblower claims.

Websites ðŸ”—

This section provides links to the official websites of AARO and NASA’s UAP study team.

Investigation and analysis of reported UFO incidents under the federal government of the United States ðŸ”—

This section serves as an introduction to the topic, stating that the US government has been investigating UFOs since 1947 through various branches and agencies. It emphasizes that despite decades of interest, no evidence supports the extraordinary origins of UFOs, attributing sightings to natural phenomena, human technology, misapprehensions, delusions, or hoaxes. It mentions the initial Air Force projects (Sign, Grudge, Blue Book) and the Condon Report’s conclusion that further UFO study was not justified. It also highlights the 2017 New York Times report on the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program (AATIP) and the Pentagon’s release of UAP videos. Finally, it notes the establishment of the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force (UAPTF), congressional hearings on UAPs, NASA’s UAP study team, and the creation of the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO).

U.S. government activity from 1947 to 1969 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the early period of US government UFO investigations, primarily through Projects Sign, Grudge, and Blue Book.

Projects Sign, Grudge, and Blue Book ðŸ”—

Dick’s analysis of the Air Force’s role in officially recognizing the extraterrestrial hypothesis. The section discusses the Mantell incident and the challenges the Air Force faced in quashing extraterrestrial rumors. It describes Project Sign’s initial extraterrestrial hypothesis, which was rejected by General Hoyt S. Vandenburg. It contrasts Project Sign with Project Grudge, which adopted a more skeptical approach. The section also highlights the role of J. Allen Hynek, who advocated for continued UFO studies. It provides statistics on the number of reported sightings investigated under these projects and the percentage that remained unidentified. Overview of government activity from 1947 to 1969 ðŸ”—

This section provides a summary of government activity during this period. It notes that most military and defense authorities concluded that UFOs posed no threat to national security, but investigations were shrouded in secrecy due to classified aviation projects. It contrasts the US approach with that of other governments, which have released formerly classified UFO documents. It also mentions J. Allen Hynek and Nick Pope as exceptions to the consensus against government investment in UFO investigations. Finally, it cites Robert Sheaffer’s assessment that Project Blue Book did not yield any significant findings.

U.S. government inactivity from 1969 to 2017 ðŸ”—

This section covers the period of nearly five decades when the US government did not have public programs for investigating UFOs. It mentions a 1977 request from Frank Press to NASA to reopen investigations, and NASA’s initial inclination to agree, followed by a decision against establishing a research activity or convening a symposium on the subject. It also notes the Air Force’s release of two investigative reports on the Roswell incident in the 1990s due to renewed media interest.

U.S. government activity from 2017 to present ðŸ”—

item.title: Calvine UFO photograph
item.description:
Calvine UFO photograph ðŸ”—

The Calvine UFO photograph, also known as the Calvine Sighting, refers to a reported UFO sighting near Calvine, Perthshire, Scotland, in August 1990. Two men reported witnessing a diamond-shaped craft while walking on the moors. They took photographs of the object as it hovered silently before ascending vertically and disappearing. The Daily Record newspaper received the story and the original prints and negatives, which were then passed to the Ministry of Defence (MOD). The original materials disappeared, and the story was never published. Investigative journalist David Clarke has led efforts to locate the witnesses. The case gained public interest over the years, with partial documentation released by The National Archives in 2009. An original photograph was discovered by Clarke and published in the Daily Mail in 2022, leading to significant media coverage.

Historical background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the Calvine sighting within the broader history of UFO photography. It mentions Nick Pope, a former Ministry of Defence desk officer, who included the Calvine sighting in his 1996 book, Open Skies, Closed Minds. Pope described the sighting as intriguing and noted that the MOD’s analysis concluded the photos were likely genuine. The object was described as a solid craft, at least the size of a Harrier or Hawk fighter jet. Sean Kirkpatrick, former director of the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, has suggested the image is a reflection and may have been doctored.

Release of MOD files ðŸ”—

This section details how the Calvine case gained more public attention after 2008 when the National Archives began releasing MOD UFO reports. David Clarke supervised the release and publication of these files. Among the released documents were materials related to the Calvine sighting, including a government briefing and handwritten summary. Two poor-quality photocopies of images were also included. These files revealed that DI55, a branch of the Directorate of Scientific and Technical Intelligence (DSTI), investigated the images along with a RAF photo analyst agency. Clarke later explored the Calvine incident in his book, The UFO Files.

2015 Channel 5 documentary ðŸ”—

The release of information from the National Archives, along with publicity from Clarke and Pope, led to increasing public interest in the case. In 2015, the incident was featured in the Channel 5 documentary series Conspiracy. The episode, titled “Alien Cover-Up”, included interviews with Clarke and Pope and featured a reconstruction of the sighting. A graphic artist recreated the Calvine photograph for the program, which was later mistaken by some for a genuine image. Pope has speculated on potential links to the alleged Aurora project.

Discovery of the Calvine photograph ðŸ”—

This section describes the renewed investigation led by David Clarke in 2018 to locate the missing photographs and witnesses. Clarke’s interest was sparked by a Defence Intelligence Officer’s claim that the witnesses had photographed a classified U.S. black project platform. Clarke and his team interviewed former MOD staff and conducted public searches. In 2020, Scottish UFOlogist Straiph Wilson launched a search for the hill walkers. Clarke eventually tracked down retired RAF Press Officer Craig Lindsay, who had kept the original photograph for over 32 years. Lindsay donated the print and other items to Sheffield Hallam University’s Special Collection. Andrew Robinson, a photographic specialist, produced high-resolution digital copies and conducted an in-depth analysis, concluding that the photograph is genuine.

The search for Kevin Russell ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the search for a person named Kevin Russell, whose name was written on the back of the original Calvine photograph. The name was believed to be that of one of the witnesses. Despite contacting over 400 people with that name, Clarke’s team was unable to identify the witness. A person named Kevin Russell who worked at a hotel in Pitlochry was identified, but he denied any knowledge of the UFO. Nick Pope acknowledges being aware of the name Kevin Russell but declined to comment.

The Program documentary (2024) ðŸ”—

This section discusses the documentary The Program by James Fox, released in December 2024, which features the Calvine UFO case. Fox interviewed David Clarke and Robinson in Sheffield and Lindsay in Scotland. The film explores the U.S. congressional effort to uncover government knowledge about UFOs and UAPs and includes an in-depth review of the Calvine case.

While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back centuries, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II. Investigations by governments, organizations, and individuals have sought to understand these phenomena, but definitive confirmation of unconventional explanations remains elusive.

While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back centuries, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II, particularly during the Space Age. Investigations into UFO reports have been conducted by governments, organizations, and individuals, but no definitive confirmation of claims suggesting extraterrestrial origins or other unconventional explanations has emerged. Skeptics often attribute UFO sightings to misidentified natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, or hoaxes.

Terminology ðŸ”—

The terms “flying saucers” or “flying discs” were initially used to describe UFOs, stemming from the Kenneth Arnold incident. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt of the USAF coined the acronym “UFO” to encompass a broader range of reported shapes and performances. “Unidentified aerial phenomena” (UAP) emerged later, gaining traction in the 21st century due to negative connotations associated with “UFO.” The term “extra-terrestrial vehicle” (ETV) is sometimes used to distinguish between extraterrestrial and earthbound explanations for UFOs.

Identification ðŸ”—

Most UFOs, upon investigation, are identified as ordinary objects or phenomena. Common sources of UFO reports include aircraft (military, civilian, experimental, drones), astronomical objects (bright stars, planets, meteors), balloons (weather, research, toy), hoaxes, light phenomena (mirages, flares, searchlights), other atmospheric objects (birds, unusual clouds, plasma), and psychological effects (pareidolia, hallucinations). Studies, such as one by CUFOS researcher Allan Hendry, have found that most sightings are honest misidentifications of prosaic phenomena due to inexperience or misperception.

History ðŸ”—

Early history before the 20th century ðŸ”—

Throughout history, people have observed unusual sights in the sky, including comets, meteors, planets, and optical phenomena. These events were often interpreted as supernatural portents or religious omens. While some UFO enthusiasts draw parallels between religious symbols in medieval paintings and UFO reports, art historians offer conventional religious interpretations.

Examples of pre-contemporary reports include:

  • Julius Obsequens’ Liber de prodigiis, which describes things moving through the sky.
  • Shen Kuo’s Dream Pool Essays, which recounts eyewitness testimony of a flying object with opening doors and blinding light in 11th-century China.
  • Woodcuts and leaflets from the 15th and 16th centuries depicting “miracles” and “sky spectacles.”
  • John Martin’s 1878 report of a large, dark, circular object resembling a balloon flying at high speed.

20th century and after ðŸ”—

During World War II, Allied and Axis pilots reported seeing round, glowing fireballs known as “foo fighters.” Explanations for these sightings ranged from St. Elmo’s fire to German secret weapons. In 1946, over 2,000 reports of unidentified aerial objects over Scandinavia, referred to as “ghost rockets,” were collected.

The modern UFO phenomenon gained momentum with the widely reported sighting by Kenneth Arnold in 1947, who described seeing “flying saucers.” This sparked a media frenzy and numerous reports of similar sightings, including the Roswell incident. UFO enthusiasts formed “saucer clubs,” and books promoting the extraterrestrial hypothesis gained popularity.

In the U.S., media accounts and speculation led to the 1952 UFO scare in Washington, D.C. From 1947 to 1969, the U.S. Air Force investigated UFO reports through Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book. The CIA also conducted a study in 1952, concluding that UFOs were real physical objects of potential threat. Public pressure for declassification of UFO records mounted, but the CIA resisted.

Official U.S. Air Force interest waned after the Condon Report in 1969, which concluded that further study of UFOs was not justified. However, some government documents suggest that non-public UFO investigations continued.

From the 1960s to 1990s, UFOs became part of popular culture’s fascination with the supernatural and paranormal. The Barney and Betty Hill alien abduction account gained notoriety, and UFO stories were featured in TV shows and films.

In December 2017, media attention resurfaced with the revelation of the secret Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program. Leaked Pentagon UFO videos led to increased mainstream interest in UFO stories. In July 2021, Harvard astronomer Avi Loeb announced the Galileo Project to seek evidence of extraterrestrial artifacts. Government-sponsored programs, such as NASA’s UAP independent study team and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, were established to investigate UFO claims. Congressional hearings were held to discuss military reports of UAPs.

Public belief in UFOs varies, with polls showing that a significant percentage of Americans believe UFOs are evidence of alien life.

item.title: Belgian UFO wave
item.description:
Belgian UFO Wave ðŸ”—

The Belgian UFO wave was a series of sightings of triangular UFOs in Belgium from November 29, 1989, to April 1990.

The Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details the timeline and specifics of the UFO sightings during the Belgian UFO wave. It began in November 1989, with reports describing a large, flat, triangular object flying at low altitude. The peak of the wave occurred on the night of March 30, 1990. On that night, an unknown object was tracked on radar, prompting the Belgian Air Force to send two F-16s to investigate. While the pilots didn’t visually confirm the object, many people claimed to have witnessed it. The Control Reporting Center (CRC) at Glons received initial reports of unusual lights moving towards Thorembais-Gembloux. Traffic Center Control at Semmerzake tracked an object on radar, leading to the scrambling of two F-16 fighters from Beauvechain Air Base. The F-16s attempted nine interceptions, achieving radar lock briefly on three occasions, but these locks were later determined to be on each other. Members of the Wavre gendarmerie reported seeing four lights in a square formation, making jerky movements before disappearing.

Patrick MarÃ©chal Hoax Photograph ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the famous “Petit-Rechain photo,” which depicted a black triangular object with lights. The photo was widely circulated and examined by various organizations, including NASA, the French National Centre for Scientific Research, and the Belgian Royal Military Academy. For two decades, the UFOlogical organization SociÃ©tÃ© belge d’Ã©tude des phÃ©nomÃ¨nes spatiaux (SOBEPS) claimed the photo was genuine. However, in 2011, photographer Patrick MarÃ©chal confessed that it was a hoax. He explained that he had constructed the UFO from a polystyrene triangle with lightbulbs to prank his workmates. Brian Dunning discussed the photograph in his Skeptoid podcast, highlighting it as emblematic of the quality of evidence during the Belgian UFO wave.

Explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores various explanations proposed for the Belgian UFO wave. In 1992, Marc Hallet criticized SOBEPS, arguing that the wave was a mass delusion fueled by misinformation. Pierre Magain and Marc Remy suggested that the phenomenon would be better studied by human scientists than physicists. Renaud Leclet and co. proposed that some sightings could be explained by helicopters, with the lack of noise attributed to environmental factors. Jean-Michel Abrassart argued that the beginning of the wave aligns with the psychosocial hypothesis. Auguste Meessen defended the unexplained nature of the wave, prompting rebuttals from Roger Paquay and Jean-Michel Abrassart. Brian Dunning discussed the F-16 chase, noting that radar locks were likely on each other due to atmospheric interference (Bragg scattering). He concludes that the sightings were a psychosocial phenomenon, explaining the lack of substantial evidence.

item.title: Black triangle (UFO)
item.description:
Black Triangles ðŸ”—

Black triangles are a type of unidentified flying object (UFO) characterized by their triangular shape and dark color. These objects are typically observed at night and are often described as large, silent, hovering, moving slowly, and displaying pulsating, colored lights that can be turned off.

British Sightings and UK Ministry of Defence Report ðŸ”—

This section discusses the analysis of black triangle sightings by the UK Ministry of Defence in a declassified report called Project Condign. The report suggests that many unexplained UAP reports could be attributed to atmospheric gaseous electrically charged buoyant plasmas. It also mentions that some observations might be due to meteor entry into the atmosphere. The report proposes that a field with undetermined characteristics can exist between charged buoyant objects in loose formation, creating a triangular shape where light reflection doesn’t occur. A recommendation from the report advises aircraft to avoid intercepting these objects and instead position them astern to reduce collision risks. The report also speculates that plasma formations could induce vivid but incorrect perceptions in observers. Mark Stenhoff and Adrian James are mentioned as authors who doubt the scientific veracity of the Project Condign report.

Other Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details various black triangle UFO sightings reported across different locations and time periods.

1980s Hudson Valley Sightings ðŸ”—

During the early 1980s, hundreds of people reported seeing UFOs over or near the Hudson River in New York state. These objects were described as hovering or slowly flying V-shaped objects with colorful lights. Some pilots claimed responsibility for these sightings, stating that the objects were ultralight aircraft flown in formation.

1989â€“1992 Belgian Wave ðŸ”—

The Belgian UFO wave began in November 1989. On November 29, over thirty groups of witnesses and three police groups documented a large, flat, triangular object with lights underneath flying at low altitude without making any sound. A report titled The Belgian UFO Wave of 1989â€“1992 â€“ A Neglected Hypothesis suggests that some sightings could be explained by helicopters, with the lack of noise attributed to engine noise in witnesses’ automobiles or strong winds. The Belgian Air Force attempted to intercept an object detected by radar during this wave, but the pilots did not visually confirm the object. Brian Dunning is mentioned as a skeptic who disputes the entire Belgian UFO wave.

1997 Phoenix Lights Incident ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the widely reported “Phoenix Lights” events, where multiple unidentified objects were observed near Phoenix, Arizona, beginning on March 13, 1997. Some objects appeared in a large “V” formation and lingered for several minutes. Residents reported that one of the black triangles was over a mile wide and drifted slowly over their houses. The US Air Force concluded that the military had been testing aircraft-launched flares during that period.

2000 Southern Illinois Incident ðŸ”—

The “St. Clair Triangle” sighting occurred on January 5, 2000, over several towns in Southern Illinois. The incident was featured in television shows, and Sufjan Stevens included it in his song “Concerning the UFO Sighting Near Highland, Illinois.” The FAA suggested that the sightings might have been due to an advertising blimp operated by the American Blimp Company. William Stage is mentioned as a source, and Eric Mack is cited for debunking his own UFO sighting.

item.title: 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident
item.description:
Washington, D.C. UFO Incident (1952) ðŸ”—

This article details a series of unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings that occurred in Washington, D.C., during July 1952. These sightings, known as the “Washington flap,” the “Washington National Airport Sightings,” or the “Invasion of Washington,” garnered significant media attention and became one of the most well-known UFO incidents.

1952 UFO flap ðŸ”—

This section describes the broader context of the 1952 UFO flap, a period of heightened media and public interest in UFO sightings. It notes the surge in reported sightings during the summer of 1952, with the US Air Force receiving over 717 new reports, compared to 615 in the previous four years. It mentions the role of media coverage, including a Life magazine article titled “Have We Visitors From Space?” which is believed to have contributed to the increased sightings. The section also highlights other notable sightings and reports leading up to the Washington D.C. events, including a UFO report filed by Hughes Aircraft Company in Los Angeles and an interception of a UFO over Boston by F-94s. The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting over Chesapeake Bay is also mentioned. Edward J. Ruppelt, the director of Project Blue Book, is a key figure mentioned in this section.

Sightings over Washington, D.C. ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the specific UFO sightings that occurred over Washington, D.C., on two consecutive Saturday nights in July 1952.

Night of July 19 ðŸ”—

This subsection details the events of the first night of sightings, beginning with air traffic controller Edward Nugent spotting seven objects on radar at Washington National Airport. Senior air-traffic controller Harry Barnes also witnessed the objects and noted their unusual movements. Controllers at the airport’s control tower, Howard Cocklin and Joe Zacko, also reported seeing unidentified blips on radar and a “bright light” in the sky. Airman William Brady at Andrews Air Force Base reported seeing an “orange ball of fire.” S.C. Pierman, a Capital Airlines pilot, observed six “white, tailless, fast-moving lights” near his plane. Staff Sgt. Charles Davenport at Andrews Air Force Base observed an orange-red light exhibiting unusual movements. Two F-94 Starfire jet fighters were dispatched from New Castle Air Force Base in Delaware, but the objects vanished from radar upon their arrival, only to reappear after the jets left.

Publicity and Air Force reaction ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the widespread media coverage of the July 19-20 sightings, which made front-page headlines across the nation. It mentions the involvement of USAF Captain Edward J. Ruppelt, the supervisor of Project Blue Book, who was in Washington at the time but faced difficulties in investigating the sightings. The section also notes that an Air Force radar specialist, Captain Roy James, suggested that unusual weather conditions could have caused the radar targets.

Night of July 26 ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the events of the second night of sightings, beginning with a pilot and stewardess on a National Airlines flight reporting lights above their plane. Radar centers at National Airport and Andrews AFB tracked more unknown objects. USAF master sergeant Charles E. Cummings visually observed the objects at Andrews. Albert M. Chop, the press spokesman for Project Blue Book, arrived at National Airport. Two F-94 Starfire jet fighters from New Castle Air Force Base were scrambled. Captain John McHugo, the flight leader, saw nothing, but his wingman, Lieutenant William Patterson, saw four white “glows” and chased them. USAF Major Dewey Fournet, Project Blue Book’s liaison at the Pentagon, and Lt. John Holcomb, a United States Navy radar specialist, arrived at the radar center at National Airport. Civilian aircraft also reported glowing objects that corresponded to radar blips.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions a report from West Palm Beach scoutmaster Sonny DesVergers, who claimed to have been burned by a flying disc on August 19.

Air Force explanation ðŸ”—

This section details the Air Force’s official explanation for the sightings. Major Generals John Samford, USAF Director of Intelligence, and Roger M. Ramey, USAF Director of Operations, held a press conference at the Pentagon on July 29, 1952. Samford stated that the visual sightings could be explained as misidentified aerial phenomena, such as stars or meteors, and the unknown radar targets could be attributed to temperature inversion. The crew of a B-25 bomber and Air Force Captain Harold May are mentioned as witnesses who supported the Air Force’s explanation. The CAA’s Technical Development and Evaluation Center also conducted an analysis that supported the temperature inversion theory. Donald Menzel and Philip Klass are mentioned as prominent UFO skeptics who also supported the temperature inversion/mirage hypothesis.

Criticisms ðŸ”—

This subsection presents criticisms of the Air Force’s explanation. Edward J. Ruppelt, in his book, noted that radar and control tower personnel, as well as some Air Force officers, disagreed with the Air Force’s explanation. Michael Wertheimer, a researcher for the Condon Report, stated that radar witnesses still disputed the Air Force explanation in 1966. Former radar controller Howard Cocklin maintained his belief that he saw an object over Washington National Airport.

White House concern and CIA interest ðŸ”—

This section discusses the concern that the sightings caused within the White House and the CIA. President Harry Truman requested an explanation of the sightings and radar returns. CIA historian Gerald Haines noted that the Truman administration was alarmed by the sightings. The CIA formed a special study group to review the situation and recommended continued monitoring of the problem. This concern led to the creation of the Robertson Panel in January 1953.

The Robertson Panel ðŸ”—

This section describes the creation and findings of the Robertson Panel, formed in January 1953 due to the high number of UFO reports. The panel, chaired by physicist Howard P. Robertson, consisted of prominent scientists who examined UFO cases collected by Project Blue Book. The panel dismissed most cases as not representing anything unusual or threatening and recommended that the Air Force and Project Blue Book focus on debunking UFO reports.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section notes the appearances of the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident in popular culture, specifically in the History Channel television series Project Blue Book and the Netflix series Top Secret UFO Projects Declassified.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the notes and sources used in the article.

item.title: 1976 Tehran UFO incident
item.description:
1976 Tehran UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The 1976 Tehran UFO incident involved radar and visual sightings of an unidentified flying object (UFO) over Tehran, Iran, in the early morning hours of September 19, 1976. Two Imperial Iranian Air Force (IIAF) F-4 Phantom II jet interceptors were dispatched to investigate. Pilots reported instrumentation and communication failures as they approached the object, which were restored upon withdrawal. One aircraft also experienced a temporary weapons systems failure while preparing to fire. An initial report was relayed to the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff on the day of the incident.

Incident ðŸ”—

On September 19, 1976, at least four civilians reported a shining object in the sky above Tehran. Lieutenant Yaddi Nazeri and a weapons officer were sent to investigate in an F-4 Phantom II. Nazeri reported losing all instruments and communications upon reaching Tehran, prompting a return to base where the instruments returned to normal.

Major Parviz Jafari, a squadron commander, and First Lieutenant Jalal Damirian were dispatched in a second F-4 Phantom II. Jafari acquired radar lock on an object 27 nautical miles away, estimating its size to be comparable to a Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker. As he approached, Jafari described the object as flashing intense red, green, orange, and blue lights. His plane’s communications system shut off. When he attempted to fire an AIM-9 Sidewinder missile, his equipment failed and only returned to normal after moving away.

Jafari reported a round object emerging from the primary object and moving towards him at high speed. His weapons control panel failed, and he lost all instruments and radio communication. Instructed to return to base, Jafari saw the primary, diamond-shaped object and another bright object descending towards the ground, emitting a bright light. The next day, Jafari and Damirian searched the area by helicopter but found nothing. Residents reported hearing a loud noise and seeing a bright flash of light.

Analysis ðŸ”—

Martin Bridgstock of Griffith University summarized the incident as Iranian air force jets investigating lights in the sky, with at least one jet experiencing electrical failures and an attempt to fire a missile. A nearby airliner also suffered radio failure.

Philip J. Klass suggested the pilots initially mistook Jupiter for a UFO. He attributed equipment failures to pilot incompetence and equipment malfunction. Klass noted that only the first F-4 reported equipment failure and had a history of electrical outages. A McDonnell Douglas repair supervisor suggested the radar might have been in “manual track” mode, leading to misinterpretation.

Bridgstock criticized UFOlogists’ reports and highlighted Klass’s findings that only one aircraft had electrical malfunctions and that the aircrews were tired and could have mistaken stars or meteors for UFOs.

Brian Dunning noted that the incident occurred during the peak of the Gamma Piscids and Southern Piscids meteorite showers, making observations of falling objects common. A beeping transponder from a C-141 aircraft was found at the supposed crash site. Dunning concluded that the Tehran 1976 UFO case was unusual only because planes chased celestial objects and experienced equipment failures.

Reference to incident in the media ðŸ”—

The Sightings television program covered the incident in 1994, interviewing participants. The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian listed it among their top 10 UFO sightings.

Gallery ðŸ”—

The gallery includes an editorial from the United States Air Force Security Services quarterly MIJI newsletter, which Dunning describes as a dramatized retelling of the incident offered as an editorial on jamming and interference.

item.title: Big Sur UFO
item.description:
The Big Sur UFO ðŸ”—

This article details a reported UFO incident that allegedly occurred during a 1964 Air Force mission near Big Sur, California. The Air Force team was stationed on a mountaintop to film Atlas missile tests from Vandenberg Air Force Base.

Air Force deployment to Anderson Peak ðŸ”—

From August to November 1964, the U.S. Air Force deployed personnel to the Los Padres National Forest in California. They used a special telescope borrowed from Boston University to photograph missile launches from Vandenberg Air Force Base. Lt. Robert Jacobs was the commander for the Big Sur location, managed by the 1369th Photo Squadron. The team successfully filmed nine launches, including one of an Atlas missile called “Buzzing Bee,” capturing footage of a re-entry vehicle deploying decoy warheads. This technology was highly classified and designed to protect American nuclear weapons from Soviet interception.

Fringe claims of extra-terrestrials ðŸ”—

In 1982, Robert Jacobs wrote about the incident in the tabloid National Enquirer, claiming he had been part of a cover-up and was now breaking his silence. He described film footage of an unidentified object next to a warhead and a senior official’s reaction. Jacobs claimed he was instructed to never discuss the film. Major Florenz Mansmann reportedly confirmed Jacobs’ account in a 1987 letter. Robert Hastings, a UFO author, further popularized the story in 2007. In 2021, Jacobs participated in a press conference to discuss his interpretation of the incident.

Decoy warheads explanation ðŸ”—

Kingston A. George, the project engineer during the incident, disputed Jacob’s claims of extraterrestrial interference in the Skeptical Inquirer. George stated that he, too, had seen footage he wasn’t cleared to see and was instructed not to speak of it. However, George claims he knew the true purpose of the test: filming the deployment of decoy warheads and chaff to confuse enemy air defenses. He attributed the lights Jacobs reported to the explosive deployment of decoys and chaff, not a UFO energy beam.

item.title: Michigan "swamp gas" UFO reports
item.description:
1966 US UFO Sightings: Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports ðŸ”—

This article details the mass sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) that occurred in Michigan during March 1966, specifically on March 20 and 21. These events became known as the “Michigan ‘swamp gas’ UFO reports” due to the Air Force’s controversial explanation for the sightings.

March 1966 UFO Flap ðŸ”—

This section provides an overview of the broader context of the Michigan UFO sightings, noting that the Dexter and Hillsdale mass sightings occurred amidst a wave of UFO reports throughout southern Michigan. A map illustrates the locations of reported sightings, including Lima, Milan, Dexter, Hillsdale, and Holland.

Initial Reports ðŸ”—

This section details the initial UFO sightings that preceded the Dexter and Hillsdale incidents. It mentions reports from Washtenaw County residents, sheriffs, and police beginning around 3:50 a.m. on March 14, describing lights moving at high speeds over Lima Township. Sightings were also reported from Monroe, Livingston, Ypsilanti, Dexter, and Sylvania. Sheriff Deputies Buford Bushroe and John Foster, along with personnel at Selfridge Air Force Base, confirmed the sightings. Deputy David Fitzpatrick captured photographs of lights over Milan on March 16.

Dexter Mass Sighting ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the events of March 20, 1966, when Frank Mannor, his wife, and son Ronald reported seeing a red “falling star” that hovered over a marshy area near their farmhouse northwest of Dexter. Mannor contacted law enforcement, and Deputy Sheriff Stanley McFadden and his partner David Fitzpatrick investigated. The Mannors described the object as football-shaped with a ‘waffled’ texture, blinking lights, and antennae. Dexter patrolman Robert Hunawil and Dexter Chief of Police Robert Taylor were also witnesses. Approximately 60 people, including law enforcement, neighbors, and the Mannor family, reportedly witnessed the UFO.

Hillsdale Mass Sighting ðŸ”—

This section describes the mass sighting that occurred around 9 p.m. on March 21 at Hillsdale College. Approximately 87 residents of the MacIntyre Residence Hall observed flashing lights hovering over the Arboretum. William Van Horn, Hillsdale County civil defense director, investigated and observed the lights through binoculars. Hillsdale police officers Harold Hess and Jerry Wise also witnessed the object and reported radio damage after the event.

Continued Reports ðŸ”—

This section notes that reports of flying objects, strange sounds, and unexplained lights continued in Dexter and Hillsdale on March 22. On March 23, a teen from Monroe claimed to have taken photos of a UFO. Robert Nichols and his wife reported an object flying across a highway near Holland on March 24. Sightings were also reported over Macomb and Oakland counties, as well as Bad Axe, Flint, and Ann Arbor, on March 29.

National Attention ðŸ”—

This section discusses the national media coverage of the Dexter sightings, noting that papers nationwide reported on the events on March 21. Wire services distributed a drawing of the reported object by a police officer. Various speculations were covered, including a theory that the UFO was filling up on swamp water to recharge its batteries.

Hynek Press Conference ðŸ”—

This section details the involvement of J. Allen Hynek, an Air Force UFO expert, who was dispatched to investigate the Dexter and Hillsdale sightings. On March 25, Hynek held a press conference where he attributed the sightings to “marsh gas,” an explanation that was met with skepticism and derision. He dismissed the Fitzpatrick photograph as being of the moon and Venus.

Reactions ðŸ”—

Congressional Hearing ðŸ”—

This section discusses Hynek’s testimony before the House Armed Services Committee on April 6, alongside Air Force Secretary Harold Brown and Bluebook chief Major Hector Quintanilla. Hynek broke with the Air Force’s stance and suggested that some aspects of UFOs merited serious study.

This section examines the long-term impact of the Michigan UFO sightings. The sightings were listed as a top-ten story for 1966 in Michigan. Alan Hynek, who popularized the swamp gas hypothesis, later argued that the topic merited serious study. The phrase “swamp gas” became associated with skepticism of government conclusions. The incident has been referenced in popular culture, including The X-Files and Men in Black.

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Flying Saucer ðŸ”—

A flying saucer, or flying disc, is a purported type of disc-shaped unidentified flying object (UFO). The term originated in 1947 when US news media reported pilot Kenneth Arnold’s claim of seeing objects flying near his airplane over Washington State. The news reports included implausible speed estimates and preceded a wave of sightings across the US, including the Roswell incident and the Flight 105 UFO sighting. A National Guard pilot died in 1948 while pursuing a flying saucer. Civilian research groups and conspiracy theories developed around the topic, and the concept spread to other countries. Early reports speculated about secret military technology, but flying saucers became associated with aliens by 1950. The terms unidentified flying object (UFO) and unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) have gradually replaced the term over time.

An aerial photo taken over Lake Cote, Costa Rica, by Sergio Loaiza in 1971 is included.

In science fiction, UFO sightings, UFO conspiracy theories, and popular culture, saucers are typically piloted by nonhuman beings. Most reported sightings describe saucers in the distance and do not mention a crew. Descriptions of the craft vary considerably. Early reports emphasized speed, but the descriptions shifted over the decades to the objects mostly hovering. They are generally said to be round, sometimes with a protrusion on top, but details of the shape vary between reports. Witnesses describe flying saucers as silent or deafening, with lights of every color, and flying alone or in formation. Size estimates range from small enough to fit in a living room to over 2,000 feet (610 m) in diameter. Sightings are most frequent at night. Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel concluded that the reports were too varied to all be describing the same type of objects. Experts have identified most reported saucers as known phenomena, including astronomical objects such as Venus, airborne objects such as balloons, and optical phenomena such as sun dogs.

1950s pop culture embraced flying saucers. The discs appeared in film, television, literature, music, toys, and advertising. Their reports influenced religious movements and were the subject of military investigations. The shape became visual shorthand for alien invaders. During the 1960s, saucers waned in popularity as UFOs were reported and depicted in other shapes. Discs ceased to be viewed as the standard shape for alien spacecraft but are still often depicted, sometimes for their retro value to evoke the early Cold War era.

History ðŸ”—

Reports of fantastical aircraft predate the first flying saucers. In antiquity, mysterious lights in the sky were interpreted as spiritual phenomena. In the 1800s, many newspapers reported massive airships with glowing lights and humming engines. These are often seen as precursors to flying saucer and UFO sightings. On January 25, 1878, the Denison Daily News printed an article in which John Martin, a local farmer, reported an object resembling a balloon flying “at wonderful speed”. The newspaper said it appeared to be about the size of a saucer from his perspective, one of the first uses of the word “saucer” in association with a UFO. An outbreak of a number of sightings of mystery airships occurred in America in 1896 and 1897. During World War II, Allied pilots reported balls of light following their planes. They named the lights foo fighters and believed they were advanced Axis aircraft.

Many aspects of the typical flying saucer first appeared in science fiction. French sociologist Bertrand MÃ©heust noted Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante (The Lightning Wheel). In the novel, a flying disc-shaped machine abducts the protagonists via a beam of light. Science fiction magazine Amazing Stories began publishing “The Shaver Mystery” in 1945. Written by Richard Sharpe Shaver and edited by Raymond A. Palmer, they were science fiction tales about technologically advanced “detrimental robots” that abducted humans, but the stories were presented as a true account of Shaver’s life. Until the magazine ceased printing The Shaver Mystery, Amazing Stories’ letter column was regularly full of readers sharing their own purportedly true sightings of the robots.

Before the flying saucer was coined as a term, fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicted flying discs. Skeptical physicist Milton Rothman noted the appearance of so-called flying saucers in the fantasy artwork of 1930s pulp science fiction magazines, by artists such as Frank R. Paul. One of Paul’s earliest depictions of a flying saucer appeared on the cover of the November 1929 issue of Hugo Gernsback’s pulp science fiction magazine Science Wonder Stories. Science fiction illustrator Frank Wu wrote that the idea of space vehicles shaped like flying saucers was imprinted in the national psyche for many years prior to 1947, when the Roswell incident took place.

Origins ðŸ”—

The modern flying saucer concept, including the association with aliens, can be traced to the 1947 Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting. On June 24, 1947, businessman and amateur pilot Kenneth Arnold landed at the Yakima, Washington airstrip. He told staff and friends that he’d seen nine unusual airborne objects. Arnold estimated their speed at 1,700 miles per hour, beyond the capabilities of known aircraft. Newspapers soon contacted Arnold for interviews. The East Oregonian reported his supposed aircraft as “saucer-like”. In a June 26 radio interview, Arnold described them as “something like a pie plate that was cut in half with a sort of a convex triangle in the rear”. Headline writers coined the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disk” (or “disc”) for the story. Arnold later told CBS News that the early coverage “did not quote me properly […] when I described how they flew, I said that they flew like they take a saucer and throw it across the water. Most of the newspapers misunderstood and misquoted that, too. They said that I said that they were saucer-like; I said that they flew in a saucer-like fashion.” The circular shape of typical flying saucers may be due to reporters mistaking Arnold’s “saucer-like” description of motion.

Arnold’s story preceded a wave of hundreds of flying saucer reports. Lieutenant Governor of Idaho Donald S. Whitehead claimed he saw a fast-moving object resembling a meteor around the time of Arnold’s sighting. In early July, head of Air Materiel Command Nathan F. Twining told reporters that “anyone seeing the objects” should contact Wright Field. The next widely publicized report was the sighting by a United Airlines crew on July 4 of nine more disc-like objects pacing their plane over Idaho.

The public was divided on the potential origin of the saucers. Arnold told military intelligence officers he suspected the discs were experimental aircraft, and early newspapers reported Arnold saying, “I don’t know what they wereâ€”unless they were guided missiles.” News media speculated on a Soviet origin, and many war veterans connected them to the foo fighters seen during World War II. A Gallup Poll found that 90% of Americans were aware of the saucer stories, and 16 percent believed they were secret military weapons, most likely American. The most common explanation given was some type of illusion or mirage. Less than one percent believed they were alien craft. One report from Seattle, Washington, described a hammer and sickle painted onto a flying disc. The stories spread to other countries, where they were influenced by local political and social concerns. In Europe, which was still recovering from the Second World War, saucers were often reported with rocket-like features. German newspapers reported flying saucers that exploded or had tails of fire. The names for the discs were largely derived from the English “flying saucer” including the French soucoupe volante, Spanish platillo volante, Portuguese disco voador, Swedish flygande tefat, German fliegende Untertasse, and Italian disco volante.

The 1947 sightings peaked in the days after the Fourth of July and declined rapidly through mid-July. Multiple organizations offered $1,000 rewards for hard proof. In the widely reported July 7, 1947, Twin Falls saucer hoax, four teenagers in Idaho fabricated a crashed disc from jukebox parts. On July 8, the Army Air Force base at Roswell, New Mexico, issued a press release saying that they had recovered a “flying disc” from a nearby ranch; the so-called Roswell UFO incident made front-page news. International media covered the military’s announcement of a crashed disc, but within 24 hours were reporting the military’s retraction and explanation that the material was balloon debris. By July 11, the most widely reported story was a North Hollywood resident’s claim that a 30-inch galvanized iron disc containing glass radio tubes had crashed in his garden. Newspapers quoted Fire Battalion Chief Wallace Newcombe’s assessment, “It doesn’t look to me like it could fly.”

The Air Force collected over a hundred reports at Wright Field, now Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio. Air Force General Nathan Twining established Project SAUCER, later renamed Project Sign, the first in a series of UFO investigations by the US Government. Other national governments followed suit. Canada began Project Magnet and the United Kingdom launched the Flying Saucer Working Party in 1950, which attributed saucer reports to meteorological phenomena, astronomical phenomena, misidentification, optical illusions, misconceptions, or hoaxes

item.title: Mariana UFO film
item.description:
Mariana UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The Mariana UFO incident occurred in August 1950 in Great Falls, Montana. It involves a sighting filmed by local baseball coach Nick Mariana, considered among the first motion picture footage of a UFO. The U.S. Air Force initially claimed the objects were reflections of two F-94 jet fighters, a claim they later retracted and then endorsed again. Multiple investigations have yielded inconclusive results.

Incident ðŸ”—

On August 15, 1950, at 11:29 am, Nick Mariana and his secretary, Virginia Raunig, spotted two bright, silvery objects rotating while flying over Great Falls at an estimated speed of 200 to 400 miles per hour. Mariana filmed the objects for sixteen seconds using his 16 mm movie camera. The Great Falls Tribune reported the sighting the next day, and Mariana showed the film to local groups.

Air Force Investigation ðŸ”—

After the Great Falls Tribune informed Wright-Patterson Air Force Base about the sighting, Captain John P. Brynildsen interviewed Mariana and Raunig at Malmstrom AFB. Brynildsen sent the film to Wright-Patterson AFB for analysis. The Air Force initially determined the objects were reflections from two F-94 jet fighters. However, controversy arose when Mariana claimed the first thirty-five frames of his film, which clearly showed the UFOs as rotating disks, were missing. The Air Force denied removing more than a single damaged frame. Edward J. Ruppelt, who later headed Project Blue Book, noted the initial lack of Air Force interest in the UFO.

Lawsuit ðŸ”—

In January 1951, Bob Considine, a writer and UFO skeptic, wrote an article for Cosmopolitan debunking famous UFO sightings, including Mariana’s. Mariana filed a slander lawsuit against Considine, which was eventually dropped in September 1955.

Later Studies ðŸ”—

In July 1952, Ruppelt convinced Mariana to allow the Air Force to reanalyze the film. Analysts at Wright-Patterson AFB ruled out birds, balloons, meteors, and reflections from F-94 jets. Ruppelt concluded the film showed an unknown object. In January 1953, the Robertson Panel, convened by the Air Force and CIA, judged the objects to be reflections of aircraft.

Baker Analysis ðŸ”—

In 1954, Greene-Rouse Productions hired Robert M.L. Baker, Jr. of Douglas Aircraft to analyze Mariana’s film for a documentary. Baker concluded that the jet reflection explanation was strained. In 1968, Baker testified before a Congressional hearing on UFOs, stating that his analysis excluded most natural phenomena. In 1969, at an AAAS UFO panel, Baker presented a paper concluding the Mariana film was unidentifiable.

Condon Report ðŸ”—

In 1966, the U.S. government funded a study of the UFO phenomenon at the University of Colorado, chaired by Edward U. Condon. Roy Craig, a skeptical physicist, and David Saunders, a psychologist interested in the Mariana incident, reinvestigated the film. They disagreed on the film’s authenticity and the removal of frames. William Hartmann, an astronomer, analyzed the film and suggested airplanes remained the principal working hypothesis, though he acknowledged arguments against it.

Legacy ðŸ”—

Copies of Mariana’s film are in the US National Archives. The film is featured in documentaries and online, and continues to be debated. Great Falls, Montana, has had over 100 UFO sightings since Mariana’s incident. In 2008, the minor league baseball team in Great Falls was renamed the Great Falls Voyagers in honor of the incident.

item.title: Levelland UFO case
item.description:
Levelland UFO Case ðŸ”—

The Levelland UFO case occurred on November 2â€“3, 1957, around Levelland, Texas. It is considered a notable UFO incident due to the number of witnesses. The US Air Force attributed the sightings to ball lightning or a severe electrical storm.

Reports ðŸ”—

On the evening of November 2, 1957, Pedro Saucedo and Joe Salaz reported a UFO sighting to the Levelland police department, claiming their truck’s engine died when a blue flash of light and a rocket-shaped object approached. Motorist Jim Wheeler reported a large, egg-shaped object blocking the road, causing his vehicle to stall. A married couple reported a bright flash of light that caused their headlights and radio to fail temporarily. Texas Technological College student Newell Wright encountered a 100-foot-long egg-shaped object that caused his car engine to sputter and die. Farmer Frank Williams reported a glowing object that caused his car’s lights and motor to stop. Ronald Martin and James Long also reported similar encounters with a brightly lit object. Sheriff Weir Clem saw a red object moving across the sky, and Fire Chief Ray Jones experienced vehicle malfunctions. The Levelland police department received a total of 15 UFO-related reports during the night.

U.S. Air Force Investigation ðŸ”—

The Levelland sightings were investigated by Project Blue Book. An Air Force sergeant spent seven hours investigating, interviewing Saucedo, Wheeler, and Wright. The Air Force concluded that a severe electrical storm, possibly ball lightning or St. Elmo’s fire, caused the sightings and auto failures, blaming engine failures on wet electrical circuits. Donald H. Menzel agreed with the Air Force explanation, attributing the events to ball lightning.

Ufologists ðŸ”—

James E. McDonald and J. Allen Hynek disputed the Air Force’s explanation, arguing that there was no electrical storm. McDonald testified that ten vehicles were stopped independently within a short area and time. Hynek concurred initially but later recognized the lack of evidence that ball lightning could stop cars and put out headlights. Ufologists also noted that the Air Force investigator did not interview nine of the fifteen witnesses.

In March 2002, KDFW aired a report about the Levelland UFO case, interviewing Sheriff Weir Clem’s widow and friends.

item.title: Time-traveler UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Time-traveler UFO hypothesis ðŸ”—

The time-traveler hypothesis, also known as chrononaut UFO, future humans, extratempestrial model, and Terminator theory, proposes that unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are humans traveling from the future using advanced technology. This concept has gained recent attention from figures like retired NASA aerospace engineer Larry Lemke, Wisconsin congressman Mike Gallagher, and filmmaker Steven Spielberg. Mainstream scholars consider this hypothesis extremely implausible, and it’s generally viewed as unorthodox even among fringe conspiracy theorists.

Antecedents ðŸ”—

This section explores the origins of the ideas that led to the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Origins of time travel speculation ðŸ”—

This subsection traces the concept of time travel from the future to the past back to its literary origins. Pierre Boitard’s 1861 book Paris avant les hommes is credited with introducing the idea, featuring a man sent back to prehistoric Earth. Camille Flammarion’s 1887 novel Lumen also explored the theme of a soul traveling through different historical periods. The section also notes that while time travel is considered physically impossible by most, theoretical research continues to explore its potential feasibility, with scientists like J. Richard Gott and Ronald Mallet speculating on the possibility of future human time travel.

Speculation of future human evolution ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the history of speculation about the future evolution of mankind. It highlights H.G. Wells’ The Time Machine as an early example of both time travel and speculative evolution. Other authors mentioned include Edgar Rice Burroughs, Olaf Stapledon, Kurt Vonnegut, Stephen Baxter, and Cevdet Mehmet KÃ¶semen. The section also identifies climate change, the technological singularity, space travel, and genetic enhancement as potential factors that could alter human evolution, leading to transhuman and posthuman scenarios.

UFOs and initial explanations ðŸ”—

This subsection provides a brief overview of the history of UFO sightings. It mentions reports of unknown objects in the skies dating back to antiquity, as well as the mystery airship sightings of the 1890s and the Foo fighters and ghost rockets during World War II. The modern UFO era is said to have begun in the summer of 1947, following Kenneth Arnold’s sighting. Initial explanations for these sightings ranged from novel US or Soviet technology to misidentification of mundane objects and mass hysteria. Fringe theories included extraterrestrial or interdimensional origins.

Formation and spread ðŸ”—

This section details the development and popularization of the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Implausibility of humanoid aliens ðŸ”—

This subsection addresses the common depiction of aliens as humanoids in contactee and alien abduction folklore. It cites George Gaylord Simpson’s 1964 article The Nonprevalence of Humanoids, which argues that it’s unlikely for extraterrestrial intelligence to exist and even more unlikely for it to be humanoid. The section also mentions Stephen Jay Gould’s thought experiment about rewinding evolution, suggesting that humans would likely not evolve again. Biologist Jack Cohen’s view on the implausibility of Grey aliens evolving a physiology similar to humans is also included.

Modern popularization ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the modern resurgence of the time-traveler hypothesis. It mentions Jacques VallÃ©e’s 1975 book The Invisible College as an early example. Other figures and works mentioned include David S. Anderson, Jenny Randles, James Herbert Brennan, and Philip J. Corso and William J. Birnes’ The Day After Roswell, which reported Hermann Oberth’s belief that the Roswell craft could have been a time machine. The History channel series Ancient Aliens is also mentioned for its episodes exploring the concept. Michael P. Masters’ book Identified Flying Objects and The Extratempestrial Model are highlighted for their in-depth exploration of the hypothesis. Tim Peake and Steven Spielberg are mentioned for their recent public comments on the theory.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This subsection lists examples of the time-traveler hypothesis in popular culture. It includes the TV series It’s About Time, Gregory Benford’s novel Timescape, David Drake’s novel Birds of Prey, Michael Crichton’s novel Sphere, the TV film Official Denial, the comic book series Blake and Mortimer, the band Yes, Jordan Peele’s movie Nope, and the movie Interstellar.

Terminology and connection to other theories ðŸ”—

This subsection clarifies the terminology used to describe the hypothesis, noting that while Michael P. Masters uses the term “extratempestrial,” the overall idea is often referred to as “the time-traveler hypothesis.” It also discusses the overlap between the time-traveler hypothesis and the interdimensional hypothesis, with figures like John Ventre and Harold E. Puthoff using the terms interchangeably. The section also notes that the time-traveler hypothesis provides an alternative explanation for the absence of future time travelers, similar to how the extraterrestrial hypothesis addresses Fermi’s paradox.

Criticism ðŸ”—

This section presents criticisms of the time-traveler hypothesis. It notes that the hypothesis is considered pseudoscientific. Neil deGrasse Tyson is quoted as calling the hypothesis illogical, and Robert Sheaffer criticizes Michael P. Masters’ work for relying on the belief that time travel is possible. David J. Darling argues that the extraterrestrial and time-travel hypotheses are equally unlikely and unnecessary. Ian Ridpath suggests that Jim Penniston’s claims about time-traveling UFOs may have been influenced by the film Official Denial. Isaac Arthur is mentioned for debunking the concept as presented in Ancient Aliens. Fabio Costa is quoted as saying that time travel requires two doors, one in the future and one in the past, raising the question of where the time machine is.

item.title: Westall UFO
item.description:
Westall UFO ðŸ”—

The Westall UFO incident refers to a reported UFO sighting that occurred on April 6, 1966, in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. The event involved multiple witnesses, including students and a teacher from Westall High School. The incident has been commemorated through documentaries, reunions, and a UFO-themed playground.

Reports ðŸ”—

On April 6, 1966, students and a teacher at Westall High School (now Westall Secondary College) reported observing a round, white, grey, or silver object with a domed top. The object reportedly descended behind trees into the Grange, an open area south of the school. Some accounts mention the object being pursued by five unidentified aircraft. Shaun Matthews, who was on vacation at the Grange, described the object as having a slight purple hue and being about twice the size of a family car.

Witness accounts varied, with some reporting the object taking off after landing, while others claimed it hovered. Students who went to the Grange after the sighting described a landing site with varying details, including a circle of grass described as burnt, “boiled,” or pressed down. The number of circles reported ranged from one to three. On April 9, 1966, air force personnel and UFO enthusiasts visited the field but found nothing of interest. The landowner subsequently burned the field to prevent further access.

Explanations ðŸ”—

The Age newspaper initially suggested the object might have been a weather balloon released from Laverton. However, checks revealed that no commercial, private, or RAAF pilots reported anything unusual in the area.

Keith Basterfield proposed that a runaway balloon from the HIBAL high-altitude balloon project, used to monitor radiation levels after British nuclear tests at Maralinga, could be a likely explanation. He cited documents indicating a test balloon launched from Mildura may have drifted off course and landed near Westall High School. Basterfield noted that HIBAL balloons had a white silver appearance with a parachute and gas tube, consistent with witness descriptions. Reports also surfaced of “men in suits” cautioning witnesses against discussing the incident, suggesting a secret government exercise.

Brian Dunning suggested that a weather balloon could explain the initial sighting. He proposed that a nylon target drogue, towed by one plane for others to chase, could account for the second part of the event. Dunning also noted that over time, descriptions of the event have become mixed with fabricated details, making it difficult to discern accurate accounts.

Media Coverage ðŸ”—

The documentary Westall ‘66 focuses on the sighting, featuring interviews conducted by ufologist Shane Ryan. Westall ‘66 has been incorporated into the national history curriculum as a lesson on critical analysis of popular portrayals of historical events. The Phenomenon, a documentary film directed and co-produced by ufologist James Fox, includes content related to the Westall UFO case.

Local Culture ðŸ”—

A witness reunion was held at Westall Tennis Club Hall on April 8, 2006, to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the incident. The City of Kingston created Grange Reserve UFO Park at The Grange Reserve in Clayton South, featuring a silver UFO with red slides to reflect the 1966 Westall UFO Incident.
